play.title: The History of Troilus and Cressida

persona.name: CALCHAS
persona.alias: a Trojan priest, taking part with the Greeks.

scene.title: SCENE I. Troy. Before Priam's palace.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: Call here my varlet; I'll unarm again: Why should I war without the walls of Troy, That find such cruel battle here within? Each Trojan that is master of his heart, Let him to field; Troilus, alas! hath none.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: Will this gear ne'er be mended?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: The Greeks are strong and skilful to their strength, Fierce to their skill and to their fierceness valiant; But I am weaker than a woman's tear, Tamer than sleep, fonder than ignorance, Less valiant than the virgin in the night And skilless as unpractised infancy.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: Well, I have told you enough of this: for my part, I'll not meddle nor make no further. He that will have a cake out of the wheat must needs tarry the grinding.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: Have I not tarried?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: Ay, the grinding; but you must tarry the bolting.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: Have I not tarried?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: Ay, the bolting, but you must tarry the leavening.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: Still have I tarried.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: Ay, to the leavening; but here's yet in the word 'hereafter' the kneading, the making of the cake, the heating of the oven and the baking; nay, you must stay the cooling too, or you may chance to burn your lips.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: Patience herself, what goddess e'er she be, Doth lesser blench at sufferance than I do. At Priam's royal table do I sit; And when fair Cressid comes into my thoughts,-- So, traitor! 'When she comes!' When is she thence?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: Well, she looked yesternight fairer than ever I saw her look, or any woman else.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: I was about to tell thee:--when my heart, As wedged with a sigh, would rive in twain, Lest Hector or my father should perceive me, I have, as when the sun doth light a storm, Buried this sigh in wrinkle of a smile: But sorrow, that is couch'd in seeming gladness, Is like that mirth fate turns to sudden sadness.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: An her hair were not somewhat darker than Helen's-- well, go to--there were no more comparison between the women: but, for my part, she is my kinswoman; I would not, as they term it, praise her: but I would somebody had heard her talk yesterday, as I did. I will not dispraise your sister Cassandra's wit, but--

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: O Pandarus! I tell thee, Pandarus,-- When I do tell thee, there my hopes lie drown'd, Reply not in how many fathoms deep They lie indrench'd. I tell thee I am mad In Cressid's love: thou answer'st 'she is fair;' Pour'st in the open ulcer of my heart Her eyes, her hair, her cheek, her gait, her voice, Handlest in thy discourse, O, that her hand, In whose comparison all whites are ink, Writing their own reproach, to whose soft seizure The cygnet's down is harsh and spirit of sense Hard as the palm of ploughman: this thou tell'st me, As true thou tell'st me, when I say I love her; But, saying thus, instead of oil and balm, Thou lay'st in every gash that love hath given me The knife that made it.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: I speak no more than truth.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: Thou dost not speak so much.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: Faith, I'll not meddle in't. Let her be as she is: if she be fair, 'tis the better for her; an she be not, she has the mends in her own hands.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: Good Pandarus, how now, Pandarus!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: I have had my labour for my travail; ill-thought on of her and ill-thought on of you; gone between and between, but small thanks for my labour.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: What, art thou angry, Pandarus? what, with me?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: Because she's kin to me, therefore she's not so fair as Helen: an she were not kin to me, she would be as fair on Friday as Helen is on Sunday. But what care I? I care not an she were a black-a-moor; 'tis all one to me.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: Say I she is not fair?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: I do not care whether you do or no. She's a fool to stay behind her father; let her to the Greeks; and so I'll tell her the next time I see her: for my part, I'll meddle nor make no more i' the matter.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: Pandarus,--

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: Not I.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: Sweet Pandarus,--

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: Pray you, speak no more to me: I will leave all as I found it, and there an end.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: Peace, you ungracious clamours! peace, rude sounds! Fools on both sides! Helen must needs be fair, When with your blood you daily paint her thus. I cannot fight upon this argument; It is too starved a subject for my sword. But Pandarus,--O gods, how do you plague me! I cannot come to Cressid but by Pandar; And he's as tetchy to be woo'd to woo. As she is stubborn-chaste against all suit. Tell me, Apollo, for thy Daphne's love, What Cressid is, what Pandar, and what we? Her bed is India; there she lies, a pearl: Between our Ilium and where she resides, Let it be call'd the wild and wandering flood, Ourself the merchant, and this sailing Pandar Our doubtful hope, our convoy and our bark.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: How now, Prince Troilus! wherefore not afield?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: Because not there: this woman's answer sorts, For womanish it is to be from thence. What news, AEneas, from the field to-day?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: That Paris is returned home and hurt.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: By whom, AEneas?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: Troilus, by Menelaus.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: Let Paris bleed; 'tis but a scar to scorn; Paris is gored with Menelaus' horn.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: Hark, what good sport is out of town to-day!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: Better at home, if 'would I might' were 'may.' But to the sport abroad: are you bound thither?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: In all swift haste.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: Come, go we then together.

scene.title: SCENE II. The Same. A street.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: Who were those went by?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: Queen Hecuba and Helen.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: And whither go they?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: Up to the eastern tower, Whose height commands as subject all the vale, To see the battle. Hector, whose patience Is, as a virtue, fix'd, to-day was moved: He chid Andromache and struck his armourer, And, like as there were husbandry in war, Before the sun rose he was harness'd light, And to the field goes he; where every flower Did, as a prophet, weep what it foresaw In Hector's wrath.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: What was his cause of anger?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: Good; and what of him?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: They say he is a very man per se, And stands alone.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: So do all men, unless they are drunk, sick, or have no legs.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: This man, lady, hath robbed many beasts of their particular additions; he is as valiant as the lion, churlish as the bear, slow as the elephant: a man into whom nature hath so crowded humours that his valour is crushed into folly, his folly sauced with discretion: there is no man hath a virtue that he hath not a glimpse of, nor any man an attaint but he carries some stain of it: he is melancholy without cause, and merry against the hair: he hath the joints of every thing, but everything so out of joint that he is a gouty Briareus, many hands and no use, or purblind Argus, all eyes and no sight.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: But how should this man, that makes me smile, make Hector angry?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: They say he yesterday coped Hector in the battle and struck him down, the disdain and shame whereof hath ever since kept Hector fasting and waking.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: Who comes here?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: Madam, your uncle Pandarus.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: Hector's a gallant man.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: As may be in the world, lady.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: What's that? what's that?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: Good morrow, uncle Pandarus.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: Good morrow, cousin Cressid: what do you talk of? Good morrow, Alexander. How do you, cousin? When were you at Ilium?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: This morning, uncle.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: What were you talking of when I came? Was Hector armed and gone ere ye came to Ilium? Helen was not up, was she?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: Hector was gone, but Helen was not up.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: Even so: Hector was stirring early.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: That were we talking of, and of his anger.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: Was he angry?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: So he says here.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: True, he was so: I know the cause too: he'll lay about him to-day, I can tell them that: and there's Troilus will not come far behind him: let them take heed of Troilus, I can tell them that too.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: What, is he angry too?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: Who, Troilus? Troilus is the better man of the two.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: O Jupiter! there's no comparison.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: What, not between Troilus and Hector? Do you know a man if you see him?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: Ay, if I ever saw him before and knew him.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: Well, I say Troilus is Troilus.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: Then you say as I say; for, I am sure, he is not Hector.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: No, nor Hector is not Troilus in some degrees.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: 'Tis just to each of them; he is himself.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: Himself! Alas, poor Troilus! I would he were.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: So he is.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: Condition, I had gone barefoot to India.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: He is not Hector.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: Himself! no, he's not himself: would a' were himself! Well, the gods are above; time must friend or end: well, Troilus, well: I would my heart were in her body. No, Hector is not a better man than Troilus.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: Excuse me.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: He is elder.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: Pardon me, pardon me.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: Th' other's not come to't; you shall tell me another tale, when th' other's come to't. Hector shall not have his wit this year.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: He shall not need it, if he have his own.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: Nor his qualities.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: No matter.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: Nor his beauty.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: 'Twould not become him; his own's better.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: You have no judgment, niece: Helen herself swore th' other day, that Troilus, for a brown favour--for so 'tis, I must confess,-- not brown neither,--

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: No, but brown.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: 'Faith, to say truth, brown and not brown.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: To say the truth, true and not true.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: She praised his complexion above Paris.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: Why, Paris hath colour enough.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: So he has.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: Then Troilus should have too much: if she praised him above, his complexion is higher than his; he having colour enough, and the other higher, is too flaming a praise for a good complexion. I had as lief Helen's golden tongue had commended Troilus for a copper nose.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: I swear to you. I think Helen loves him better than Paris.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: Then she's a merry Greek indeed.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: Nay, I am sure she does. She came to him th' other day into the compassed window,--and, you know, he has not past three or four hairs on his chin,--

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: Indeed, a tapster's arithmetic may soon bring his particulars therein to a total.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: Why, he is very young: and yet will he, within three pound, lift as much as his brother Hector.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: Is he so young a man and so old a lifter?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: But to prove to you that Helen loves him: she came and puts me her white hand to his cloven chin--

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: Juno have mercy! how came it cloven?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: Why, you know 'tis dimpled: I think his smiling becomes him better than any man in all Phrygia.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: O, he smiles valiantly.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: Does he not?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: O yes, an 'twere a cloud in autumn.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: Why, go to, then: but to prove to you that Helen loves Troilus,--

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: Troilus will stand to the proof, if you'll prove it so.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: Troilus! why, he esteems her no more than I esteem an addle egg.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: If you love an addle egg as well as you love an idle head, you would eat chickens i' the shell.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: I cannot choose but laugh, to think how she tickled his chin: indeed, she has a marvellous white hand, I must needs confess,--

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: Without the rack.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: And she takes upon her to spy a white hair on his chin.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: Alas, poor chin! many a wart is richer.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: But there was such laughing! Queen Hecuba laughed that her eyes ran o'er.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: With mill-stones.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: And Cassandra laughed.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: But there was more temperate fire under the pot of her eyes: did her eyes run o'er too?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: And Hector laughed.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: At what was all this laughing?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: Marry, at the white hair that Helen spied on Troilus' chin.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: An't had been a green hair, I should have laughed too.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: They laughed not so much at the hair as at his pretty answer.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: What was his answer?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: Quoth she, 'Here's but two and fifty hairs on your chin, and one of them is white.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: This is her question.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: That's true; make no question of that. 'Two and fifty hairs' quoth he, 'and one white: that white hair is my father, and all the rest are his sons.' 'Jupiter!' quoth she, 'which of these hairs is Paris, my husband? 'The forked one,' quoth he, 'pluck't out, and give it him.' But there was such laughing! and Helen so blushed, an Paris so chafed, and all the rest so laughed, that it passed.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: So let it now; for it has been while going by.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: Well, cousin. I told you a thing yesterday; think on't.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: So I do.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: I'll be sworn 'tis true; he will weep you, an 'twere a man born in April.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: And I'll spring up in his tears, an 'twere a nettle against May.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: Hark! they are coming from the field: shall we stand up here, and see them as they pass toward Ilium? good niece, do, sweet niece Cressida.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: At your pleasure.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: Here, here, here's an excellent place; here we may see most bravely: I'll tell you them all by their names as they pass by; but mark Troilus above the rest.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: Speak not so loud.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: That's AEneas: is not that a brave man? he's one of the flowers of Troy, I can tell you: but mark Troilus; you shall see anon.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: Who's that?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: That's Antenor: he has a shrewd wit, I can tell you; and he's a man good enough, he's one o' the soundest judgments in whosoever, and a proper man of person. When comes Troilus? I'll show you Troilus anon: if he see me, you shall see him nod at me.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: Will he give you the nod?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: You shall see.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: If he do, the rich shall have more.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: That's Hector, that, that, look you, that; there's a fellow! Go thy way, Hector! There's a brave man, niece. O brave Hector! Look how he looks! there's a countenance! is't not a brave man?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: O, a brave man!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: Is a' not? it does a man's heart good. Look you what hacks are on his helmet! look you yonder, do you see? look you there: there's no jesting; there's laying on, take't off who will, as they say: there be hacks!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: Be those with swords?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: Swords! any thing, he cares not; an the devil come to him, it's all one: by God's lid, it does one's heart good. Yonder comes Paris, yonder comes Paris. Look ye yonder, niece; is't not a gallant man too, is't not? Why, this is brave now. Who said he came hurt home to-day? he's not hurt: why, this will do Helen's heart good now, ha! Would I could see Troilus now! You shall see Troilus anon.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: Who's that?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: That's Helenus. I marvel where Troilus is. That's Helenus. I think he went not forth to-day. That's Helenus.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: Can Helenus fight, uncle?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: Helenus? no. Yes, he'll fight indifferent well. I marvel where Troilus is. Hark! do you not hear the people cry 'Troilus'? Helenus is a priest.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: What sneaking fellow comes yonder?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: Where? yonder? that's Deiphobus. 'Tis Troilus! there's a man, niece! Hem! Brave Troilus! the prince of chivalry!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: Peace, for shame, peace!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: Mark him; note him. O brave Troilus! Look well upon him, niece: look you how his sword is bloodied, and his helm more hacked than Hector's, and how he looks, and how he goes! O admirable youth! he ne'er saw three and twenty. Go thy way, Troilus, go thy way! Had I a sister were a grace, or a daughter a goddess, he should take his choice. O admirable man! Paris? Paris is dirt to him; and, I warrant, Helen, to change, would give an eye to boot.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: Here come more.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: Asses, fools, dolts! chaff and bran, chaff and bran! porridge after meat! I could live and die i' the eyes of Troilus. Ne'er look, ne'er look: the eagles are gone: crows and daws, crows and daws! I had rather be such a man as Troilus than Agamemnon and all Greece.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: There is among the Greeks Achilles, a better man than Troilus.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: Achilles! a drayman, a porter, a very camel.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: Well, well.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: 'Well, well!' why, have you any discretion? have you any eyes? Do you know what a man is? Is not birth, beauty, good shape, discourse, manhood, learning, gentleness, virtue, youth, liberality, and such like, the spice and salt that season a man?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: Ay, a minced man: and then to be baked with no date in the pie, for then the man's date's out.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: You are such a woman! one knows not at what ward you lie.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: Upon my back, to defend my belly; upon my wit, to defend my wiles; upon my secrecy, to defend mine honesty; my mask, to defend my beauty; and you, to defend all these: and at all these wards I lie, at a thousand watches.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: Say one of your watches.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: Nay, I'll watch you for that; and that's one of the chiefest of them too: if I cannot ward what I would not have hit, I can watch you for telling how I took the blow; unless it swell past hiding, and then it's past watching.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: You are such another!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: Sir, my lord would instantly speak with you.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: Where?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: At your own house; there he unarms him.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: Good boy, tell him I come. I doubt he be hurt. Fare ye well, good niece.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: Adieu, uncle.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: I'll be with you, niece, by and by.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: To bring, uncle?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: Ay, a token from Troilus.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The Same. A street.
speech.text: By the same token, you are a bawd. Words, vows, gifts, tears, and love's full sacrifice, He offers in another's enterprise; But more in Troilus thousand fold I see Than in the glass of Pandar's praise may be; Yet hold I off. Women are angels, wooing: Things won are done; joy's soul lies in the doing. That she beloved knows nought that knows not this: Men prize the thing ungain'd more than it is: That she was never yet that ever knew Love got so sweet as when desire did sue. Therefore this maxim out of love I teach: Achievement is command; ungain'd, beseech: Then though my heart's content firm love doth bear, Nothing of that shall from mine eyes appear.

scene.title: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Agamemnon's tent.

speech.stagedir: Sennet. Enter AGAMEMNON, NESTOR, ULYSSES, MENELAUS, and others
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Agamemnon's tent.
speech.text: Princes, What grief hath set the jaundice on your cheeks? The ample proposition that hope makes In all designs begun on earth below Fails in the promised largeness: cheques and disasters Grow in the veins of actions highest rear'd, As knots, by the conflux of meeting sap, Infect the sound pine and divert his grain Tortive and errant from his course of growth. Nor, princes, is it matter new to us That we come short of our suppose so far That after seven years' siege yet Troy walls stand; Sith every action that hath gone before, Whereof we have record, trial did draw Bias and thwart, not answering the aim, And that unbodied figure of the thought That gave't surmised shape. Why then, you princes, Do you with cheeks abash'd behold our works, And call them shames? which are indeed nought else But the protractive trials of great Jove To find persistive constancy in men: The fineness of which metal is not found In fortune's love; for then the bold and coward, The wise and fool, the artist and unread, The hard and soft seem all affined and kin: But, in the wind and tempest of her frown, Distinction, with a broad and powerful fan, Puffing at all, winnows the light away; And what hath mass or matter, by itself Lies rich in virtue and unmingled.

speech.stagedir: Sennet. Enter AGAMEMNON, NESTOR, ULYSSES, MENELAUS, and others
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Agamemnon's tent.
speech.text: With due observance of thy godlike seat, Great Agamemnon, Nestor shall apply Thy latest words. In the reproof of chance Lies the true proof of men: the sea being smooth, How many shallow bauble boats dare sail Upon her patient breast, making their way With those of nobler bulk! But let the ruffian Boreas once enrage The gentle Thetis, and anon behold The strong-ribb'd bark through liquid mountains cut, Bounding between the two moist elements, Like Perseus' horse: where's then the saucy boat Whose weak untimber'd sides but even now Co-rivall'd greatness? Either to harbour fled, Or made a toast for Neptune. Even so Doth valour's show and valour's worth divide In storms of fortune; for in her ray and brightness The herd hath more annoyance by the breeze Than by the tiger; but when the splitting wind Makes flexible the knees of knotted oaks, And flies fled under shade, why, then the thing of courage As roused with rage with rage doth sympathize, And with an accent tuned in selfsame key Retorts to chiding fortune.

speech.stagedir: Sennet. Enter AGAMEMNON, NESTOR, ULYSSES, MENELAUS, and others
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Agamemnon's tent.
speech.text: Agamemnon, Thou great commander, nerve and bone of Greece, Heart of our numbers, soul and only spirit. In whom the tempers and the minds of all Should be shut up, hear what Ulysses speaks. Besides the applause and approbation To which, most mighty for thy place and sway, And thou most reverend for thy stretch'd-out life I give to both your speeches, which were such As Agamemnon and the hand of Greece Should hold up high in brass, and such again As venerable Nestor, hatch'd in silver, Should with a bond of air, strong as the axle-tree On which heaven rides, knit all the Greekish ears To his experienced tongue, yet let it please both, Thou great, and wise, to hear Ulysses speak.

speech.stagedir: Sennet. Enter AGAMEMNON, NESTOR, ULYSSES, MENELAUS, and others
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Agamemnon's tent.
speech.text: Speak, prince of Ithaca; and be't of less expect That matter needless, of importless burden, Divide thy lips, than we are confident, When rank Thersites opes his mastic jaws, We shall hear music, wit and oracle.

speech.stagedir: Sennet. Enter AGAMEMNON, NESTOR, ULYSSES, MENELAUS, and others
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Agamemnon's tent.
speech.text: Troy, yet upon his basis, had been down, And the great Hector's sword had lack'd a master, But for these instances. The specialty of rule hath been neglected: And, look, how many Grecian tents do stand Hollow upon this plain, so many hollow factions. When that the general is not like the hive To whom the foragers shall all repair, What honey is expected? Degree being vizarded, The unworthiest shows as fairly in the mask. The heavens themselves, the planets and this centre Observe degree, priority and place, Insisture, course, proportion, season, form, Office and custom, in all line of order; And therefore is the glorious planet Sol In noble eminence enthroned and sphered Amidst the other; whose medicinable eye Corrects the ill aspects of planets evil, And posts, like the commandment of a king, Sans cheque to good and bad: but when the planets In evil mixture to disorder wander, What plagues and what portents! what mutiny! What raging of the sea! shaking of earth! Commotion in the winds! frights, changes, horrors, Divert and crack, rend and deracinate The unity and married calm of states Quite from their fixure! O, when degree is shaked, Which is the ladder to all high designs, Then enterprise is sick! How could communities, Degrees in schools and brotherhoods in cities, Peaceful commerce from dividable shores, The primogenitive and due of birth, Prerogative of age, crowns, sceptres, laurels, But by degree, stand in authentic place? Take but degree away, untune that string, And, hark, what discord follows! each thing meets In mere oppugnancy: the bounded waters Should lift their bosoms higher than the shores And make a sop of all this solid globe: Strength should be lord of imbecility, And the rude son should strike his father dead: Force should be right; or rather, right and wrong, Between whose endless jar justice resides, Should lose their names, and so should justice too. Then every thing includes itself in power, Power into will, will into appetite; And appetite, an universal wolf, So doubly seconded with will and power, Must make perforce an universal prey, And last eat up himself. Great Agamemnon, This chaos, when degree is suffocate, Follows the choking. And this neglection of degree it is That by a pace goes backward, with a purpose It hath to climb. The general's disdain'd By him one step below, he by the next, That next by him beneath; so every step, Exampled by the first pace that is sick Of his superior, grows to an envious fever Of pale and bloodless emulation: And 'tis this fever that keeps Troy on foot, Not her own sinews. To end a tale of length, Troy in our weakness stands, not in her strength.

speech.stagedir: Sennet. Enter AGAMEMNON, NESTOR, ULYSSES, MENELAUS, and others
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Agamemnon's tent.
speech.text: Most wisely hath Ulysses here discover'd The fever whereof all our power is sick.

speech.stagedir: Sennet. Enter AGAMEMNON, NESTOR, ULYSSES, MENELAUS, and others
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Agamemnon's tent.
speech.text: The nature of the sickness found, Ulysses, What is the remedy?

speech.stagedir: Sennet. Enter AGAMEMNON, NESTOR, ULYSSES, MENELAUS, and others
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Agamemnon's tent.
speech.text: The great Achilles, whom opinion crowns The sinew and the forehand of our host, Having his ear full of his airy fame, Grows dainty of his worth, and in his tent Lies mocking our designs: with him Patroclus Upon a lazy bed the livelong day Breaks scurril jests; And with ridiculous and awkward action, Which, slanderer, he imitation calls, He pageants us. Sometime, great Agamemnon, Thy topless deputation he puts on, And, like a strutting player, whose conceit Lies in his hamstring, and doth think it rich To hear the wooden dialogue and sound 'Twixt his stretch'd footing and the scaffoldage,-- Such to-be-pitied and o'er-wrested seeming He acts thy greatness in: and when he speaks, 'Tis like a chime a-mending; with terms unsquared, Which, from the tongue of roaring Typhon dropp'd Would seem hyperboles. At this fusty stuff The large Achilles, on his press'd bed lolling, From his deep chest laughs out a loud applause; Cries 'Excellent! 'tis Agamemnon just. Now play me Nestor; hem, and stroke thy beard, As he being drest to some oration.' That's done, as near as the extremest ends Of parallels, as like as Vulcan and his wife: Yet god Achilles still cries 'Excellent! 'Tis Nestor right. Now play him me, Patroclus, Arming to answer in a night alarm.' And then, forsooth, the faint defects of age Must be the scene of mirth; to cough and spit, And, with a palsy-fumbling on his gorget, Shake in and out the rivet: and at this sport Sir Valour dies; cries 'O, enough, Patroclus; Or give me ribs of steel! I shall split all In pleasure of my spleen.' And in this fashion, All our abilities, gifts, natures, shapes, Severals and generals of grace exact, Achievements, plots, orders, preventions, Excitements to the field, or speech for truce, Success or loss, what is or is not, serves As stuff for these two to make paradoxes.

speech.stagedir: Sennet. Enter AGAMEMNON, NESTOR, ULYSSES, MENELAUS, and others
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Agamemnon's tent.
speech.text: And in the imitation of these twain-- Who, as Ulysses says, opinion crowns With an imperial voice--many are infect. Ajax is grown self-will'd, and bears his head In such a rein, in full as proud a place As broad Achilles; keeps his tent like him; Makes factious feasts; rails on our state of war, Bold as an oracle, and sets Thersites, A slave whose gall coins slanders like a mint, To match us in comparisons with dirt, To weaken and discredit our exposure, How rank soever rounded in with danger.

speech.stagedir: Sennet. Enter AGAMEMNON, NESTOR, ULYSSES, MENELAUS, and others
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Agamemnon's tent.
speech.text: They tax our policy, and call it cowardice, Count wisdom as no member of the war, Forestall prescience, and esteem no act But that of hand: the still and mental parts, That do contrive how many hands shall strike, When fitness calls them on, and know by measure Of their observant toil the enemies' weight,-- Why, this hath not a finger's dignity: They call this bed-work, mappery, closet-war; So that the ram that batters down the wall, For the great swing and rudeness of his poise, They place before his hand that made the engine, Or those that with the fineness of their souls By reason guide his execution.

speech.stagedir: Sennet. Enter AGAMEMNON, NESTOR, ULYSSES, MENELAUS, and others
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Agamemnon's tent.
speech.text: Let this be granted, and Achilles' horse Makes many Thetis' sons.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Agamemnon's tent.
speech.text: What trumpet? look, Menelaus.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Agamemnon's tent.
speech.text: From Troy.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Agamemnon's tent.
speech.text: What would you 'fore our tent?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Agamemnon's tent.
speech.text: Is this great Agamemnon's tent, I pray you?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Agamemnon's tent.
speech.text: Even this.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Agamemnon's tent.
speech.text: May one, that is a herald and a prince, Do a fair message to his kingly ears?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Agamemnon's tent.
speech.text: With surety stronger than Achilles' arm 'Fore all the Greekish heads, which with one voice Call Agamemnon head and general.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Agamemnon's tent.
speech.text: Fair leave and large security. How may A stranger to those most imperial looks Know them from eyes of other mortals?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Agamemnon's tent.
speech.text: How!

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Agamemnon's tent.
speech.text: Ay; I ask, that I might waken reverence, And bid the cheek be ready with a blush Modest as morning when she coldly eyes The youthful Phoebus: Which is that god in office, guiding men? Which is the high and mighty Agamemnon?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Agamemnon's tent.
speech.text: This Trojan scorns us; or the men of Troy Are ceremonious courtiers.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Agamemnon's tent.
speech.text: Courtiers as free, as debonair, unarm'd, As bending angels; that's their fame in peace: But when they would seem soldiers, they have galls, Good arms, strong joints, true swords; and, Jove's accord, Nothing so full of heart. But peace, AEneas, Peace, Trojan; lay thy finger on thy lips! The worthiness of praise distains his worth, If that the praised himself bring the praise forth: But what the repining enemy commends, That breath fame blows; that praise, sole sure, transcends.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Agamemnon's tent.
speech.text: Sir, you of Troy, call you yourself AEneas?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Agamemnon's tent.
speech.text: Ay, Greek, that is my name.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Agamemnon's tent.
speech.text: What's your affair I pray you?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Agamemnon's tent.
speech.text: Sir, pardon; 'tis for Agamemnon's ears.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Agamemnon's tent.
speech.text: He hears naught privately that comes from Troy.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Agamemnon's tent.
speech.text: Nor I from Troy come not to whisper him: I bring a trumpet to awake his ear, To set his sense on the attentive bent, And then to speak.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Agamemnon's tent.
speech.text: Speak frankly as the wind; It is not Agamemnon's sleeping hour: That thou shalt know. Trojan, he is awake, He tells thee so himself.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Agamemnon's tent.
speech.text: Trumpet, blow loud, Send thy brass voice through all these lazy tents; And every Greek of mettle, let him know, What Troy means fairly shall be spoke aloud. We have, great Agamemnon, here in Troy A prince call'd Hector,--Priam is his father,-- Who in this dull and long-continued truce Is rusty grown: he bade me take a trumpet, And to this purpose speak. Kings, princes, lords! If there be one among the fair'st of Greece That holds his honour higher than his ease, That seeks his praise more than he fears his peril, That knows his valour, and knows not his fear, That loves his mistress more than in confession, With truant vows to her own lips he loves, And dare avow her beauty and her worth In other arms than hers,--to him this challenge. Hector, in view of Trojans and of Greeks, Shall make it good, or do his best to do it, He hath a lady, wiser, fairer, truer, Than ever Greek did compass in his arms, And will to-morrow with his trumpet call Midway between your tents and walls of Troy, To rouse a Grecian that is true in love: If any come, Hector shall honour him; If none, he'll say in Troy when he retires, The Grecian dames are sunburnt and not worth The splinter of a lance. Even so much.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Agamemnon's tent.
speech.text: This shall be told our lovers, Lord AEneas; If none of them have soul in such a kind, We left them all at home: but we are soldiers; And may that soldier a mere recreant prove, That means not, hath not, or is not in love! If then one is, or hath, or means to be, That one meets Hector; if none else, I am he.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Agamemnon's tent.
speech.text: Tell him of Nestor, one that was a man When Hector's grandsire suck'd: he is old now; But if there be not in our Grecian host One noble man that hath one spark of fire, To answer for his love, tell him from me I'll hide my silver beard in a gold beaver And in my vantbrace put this wither'd brawn, And meeting him will tell him that my lady Was fairer than his grandam and as chaste As may be in the world: his youth in flood, I'll prove this truth with my three drops of blood.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Agamemnon's tent.
speech.text: Now heavens forbid such scarcity of youth!

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Agamemnon's tent.
speech.text: Amen.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Agamemnon's tent.

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all but ULYSSES and NESTOR
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Agamemnon's tent.
speech.text: Nestor!

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all but ULYSSES and NESTOR
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Agamemnon's tent.
speech.text: What says Ulysses?

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all but ULYSSES and NESTOR
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Agamemnon's tent.
speech.text: I have a young conception in my brain; Be you my time to bring it to some shape.

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all but ULYSSES and NESTOR
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Agamemnon's tent.
speech.text: What is't?

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all but ULYSSES and NESTOR
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Agamemnon's tent.
speech.text: This 'tis: Blunt wedges rive hard knots: the seeded pride That hath to this maturity blown up In rank Achilles must or now be cropp'd, Or, shedding, breed a nursery of like evil, To overbulk us all.

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all but ULYSSES and NESTOR
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Agamemnon's tent.
speech.text: Well, and how?

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all but ULYSSES and NESTOR
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Agamemnon's tent.
speech.text: This challenge that the gallant Hector sends, However it is spread in general name, Relates in purpose only to Achilles.

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all but ULYSSES and NESTOR
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Agamemnon's tent.
speech.text: The purpose is perspicuous even as substance, Whose grossness little characters sum up: And, in the publication, make no strain, But that Achilles, were his brain as barren As banks of Libya,--though, Apollo knows, 'Tis dry enough,--will, with great speed of judgment, Ay, with celerity, find Hector's purpose Pointing on him.

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all but ULYSSES and NESTOR
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Agamemnon's tent.
speech.text: And wake him to the answer, think you?

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all but ULYSSES and NESTOR
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Agamemnon's tent.
speech.text: Yes, 'tis most meet: whom may you else oppose, That can from Hector bring his honour off, If not Achilles? Though't be a sportful combat, Yet in the trial much opinion dwells; For here the Trojans taste our dear'st repute With their finest palate: and trust to me, Ulysses, Our imputation shall be oddly poised In this wild action; for the success, Although particular, shall give a scantling Of good or bad unto the general; And in such indexes, although small pricks To their subsequent volumes, there is seen The baby figure of the giant mass Of things to come at large. It is supposed He that meets Hector issues from our choice And choice, being mutual act of all our souls, Makes merit her election, and doth boil, As 'twere from us all, a man distill'd Out of our virtues; who miscarrying, What heart receives from hence the conquering part, To steel a strong opinion to themselves? Which entertain'd, limbs are his instruments, In no less working than are swords and bows Directive by the limbs.

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all but ULYSSES and NESTOR
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Agamemnon's tent.
speech.text: Give pardon to my speech: Therefore 'tis meet Achilles meet not Hector. Let us, like merchants, show our foulest wares, And think, perchance, they'll sell; if not, The lustre of the better yet to show, Shall show the better. Do not consent That ever Hector and Achilles meet; For both our honour and our shame in this Are dogg'd with two strange followers.

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all but ULYSSES and NESTOR
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Agamemnon's tent.
speech.text: I see them not with my old eyes: what are they?

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all but ULYSSES and NESTOR
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Agamemnon's tent.
speech.text: What glory our Achilles shares from Hector, Were he not proud, we all should share with him: But he already is too insolent; And we were better parch in Afric sun Than in the pride and salt scorn of his eyes, Should he 'scape Hector fair: if he were foil'd, Why then, we did our main opinion crush In taint of our best man. No, make a lottery; And, by device, let blockish Ajax draw The sort to fight with Hector: among ourselves Give him allowance for the better man; For that will physic the great Myrmidon Who broils in loud applause, and make him fall His crest that prouder than blue Iris bends. If the dull brainless Ajax come safe off, We'll dress him up in voices: if he fail, Yet go we under our opinion still That we have better men. But, hit or miss, Our project's life this shape of sense assumes: Ajax employ'd plucks down Achilles' plumes.

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all but ULYSSES and NESTOR
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Agamemnon's tent.
speech.text: Ulysses, Now I begin to relish thy advice; And I will give a taste of it forthwith To Agamemnon: go we to him straight. Two curs shall tame each other: pride alone Must tarre the mastiffs on, as 'twere their bone.

scene.title: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
speech.text: Thersites!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
speech.text: Agamemnon, how if he had boils? full, all over, generally?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
speech.text: Thersites!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
speech.text: And those boils did run? say so: did not the general run then? were not that a botchy core?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
speech.text: Dog!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
speech.text: Then would come some matter from him; I see none now.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
speech.text: Thou bitch-wolf's son, canst thou not hear? Feel, then.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
speech.text: The plague of Greece upon thee, thou mongrel beef-witted lord!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
speech.text: Speak then, thou vinewedst leaven, speak: I will beat thee into handsomeness.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
speech.text: I shall sooner rail thee into wit and holiness: but, I think, thy horse will sooner con an oration than thou learn a prayer without book. Thou canst strike, canst thou? a red murrain o' thy jade's tricks!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
speech.text: Toadstool, learn me the proclamation.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
speech.text: Dost thou think I have no sense, thou strikest me thus?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
speech.text: The proclamation!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
speech.text: Thou art proclaimed a fool, I think.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
speech.text: Do not, porpentine, do not: my fingers itch.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
speech.text: I would thou didst itch from head to foot and I had the scratching of thee; I would make thee the loathsomest scab in Greece. When thou art forth in the incursions, thou strikest as slow as another.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
speech.text: I say, the proclamation!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
speech.text: Thou grumblest and railest every hour on Achilles, and thou art as full of envy at his greatness as Cerberus is at Proserpine's beauty, ay, that thou barkest at him.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
speech.text: Mistress Thersites!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
speech.text: Thou shouldest strike him.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
speech.text: Cobloaf!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
speech.text: He would pun thee into shivers with his fist, as a sailor breaks a biscuit.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
speech.text: You whoreson cur!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
speech.text: Do, do.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
speech.text: Thou stool for a witch!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
speech.text: Ay, do, do; thou sodden-witted lord! thou hast no more brain than I have in mine elbows; an assinego may tutor thee: thou scurvy-valiant ass! thou art here but to thrash Trojans; and thou art bought and sold among those of any wit, like a barbarian slave. If thou use to beat me, I will begin at thy heel, and tell what thou art by inches, thou thing of no bowels, thou!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
speech.text: You dog!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
speech.text: You scurvy lord!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
speech.text: You cur!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
speech.text: Mars his idiot! do, rudeness; do, camel; do, do.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
speech.text: Why, how now, Ajax! wherefore do you thus? How now, Thersites! what's the matter, man?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
speech.text: You see him there, do you?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
speech.text: Ay; what's the matter?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
speech.text: Nay, look upon him.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
speech.text: So I do: what's the matter?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
speech.text: Nay, but regard him well.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
speech.text: 'Well!' why, I do so.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
speech.text: But yet you look not well upon him; for whosoever you take him to be, he is Ajax.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
speech.text: I know that, fool.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
speech.text: Ay, but that fool knows not himself.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
speech.text: Therefore I beat thee.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
speech.text: Lo, lo, lo, lo, what modicums of wit he utters! his evasions have ears thus long. I have bobbed his brain more than he has beat my bones: I will buy nine sparrows for a penny, and his pia mater is not worth the nineth part of a sparrow. This lord, Achilles, Ajax, who wears his wit in his belly and his guts in his head, I'll tell you what I say of him.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
speech.text: What?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
speech.text: I say, this Ajax--

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
speech.text: Nay, good Ajax.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
speech.text: Has not so much wit--

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
speech.text: Nay, I must hold you.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
speech.text: As will stop the eye of Helen's needle, for whom he comes to fight.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
speech.text: Peace, fool!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
speech.text: I would have peace and quietness, but the fool will not: he there: that he: look you there.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
speech.text: O thou damned cur! I shall--

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
speech.text: Will you set your wit to a fool's?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
speech.text: No, I warrant you; for a fools will shame it.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
speech.text: Good words, Thersites.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
speech.text: What's the quarrel?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
speech.text: I bade the vile owl go learn me the tenor of the proclamation, and he rails upon me.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
speech.text: I serve thee not.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
speech.text: Well, go to, go to.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
speech.text: I serve here voluntarily.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
speech.text: Your last service was sufferance, 'twas not voluntary: no man is beaten voluntary: Ajax was here the voluntary, and you as under an impress.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
speech.text: E'en so; a great deal of your wit, too, lies in your sinews, or else there be liars. Hector have a great catch, if he knock out either of your brains: a' were as good crack a fusty nut with no kernel.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
speech.text: What, with me too, Thersites?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
speech.text: There's Ulysses and old Nestor, whose wit was mouldy ere your grandsires had nails on their toes, yoke you like draught-oxen and make you plough up the wars.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
speech.text: What, what?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
speech.text: Yes, good sooth: to, Achilles! to, Ajax! to!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
speech.text: I shall cut out your tongue.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
speech.text: 'Tis no matter! I shall speak as much as thou afterwards.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
speech.text: No more words, Thersites; peace!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
speech.text: I will hold my peace when Achilles' brach bids me, shall I?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
speech.text: There's for you, Patroclus.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
speech.text: I will see you hanged, like clotpoles, ere I come any more to your tents: I will keep where there is wit stirring and leave the faction of fools.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
speech.text: A good riddance.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
speech.text: Marry, this, sir, is proclaim'd through all our host: That Hector, by the fifth hour of the sun, Will with a trumpet 'twixt our tents and Troy To-morrow morning call some knight to arms That hath a stomach; and such a one that dare Maintain--I know not what: 'tis trash. Farewell.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
speech.text: Farewell. Who shall answer him?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
speech.text: I know not: 'tis put to lottery; otherwise He knew his man.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. A part of the Grecian camp.
speech.text: O, meaning you. I will go learn more of it.

scene.title: SCENE II. Troy. A room in Priam's palace.

speech.stagedir: Enter PRIAM, HECTOR, TROILUS, PARIS, and HELENUS
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Troy. A room in Priam's palace.
speech.text: After so many hours, lives, speeches spent, Thus once again says Nestor from the Greeks: 'Deliver Helen, and all damage else-- As honour, loss of time, travail, expense, Wounds, friends, and what else dear that is consumed In hot digestion of this cormorant war-- Shall be struck off.' Hector, what say you to't?

speech.stagedir: Enter PRIAM, HECTOR, TROILUS, PARIS, and HELENUS
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Troy. A room in Priam's palace.
speech.text: Though no man lesser fears the Greeks than I As far as toucheth my particular, Yet, dread Priam, There is no lady of more softer bowels, More spongy to suck in the sense of fear, More ready to cry out 'Who knows what follows?' Than Hector is: the wound of peace is surety, Surety secure; but modest doubt is call'd The beacon of the wise, the tent that searches To the bottom of the worst. Let Helen go: Since the first sword was drawn about this question, Every tithe soul, 'mongst many thousand dismes, Hath been as dear as Helen; I mean, of ours: If we have lost so many tenths of ours, To guard a thing not ours nor worth to us, Had it our name, the value of one ten, What merit's in that reason which denies The yielding of her up?

speech.stagedir: Enter PRIAM, HECTOR, TROILUS, PARIS, and HELENUS
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Troy. A room in Priam's palace.
speech.text: Fie, fie, my brother! Weigh you the worth and honour of a king So great as our dread father in a scale Of common ounces? will you with counters sum The past proportion of his infinite? And buckle in a waist most fathomless With spans and inches so diminutive As fears and reasons? fie, for godly shame!

speech.stagedir: Enter PRIAM, HECTOR, TROILUS, PARIS, and HELENUS
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Troy. A room in Priam's palace.
speech.text: No marvel, though you bite so sharp at reasons, You are so empty of them. Should not our father Bear the great sway of his affairs with reasons, Because your speech hath none that tells him so?

speech.stagedir: Enter PRIAM, HECTOR, TROILUS, PARIS, and HELENUS
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Troy. A room in Priam's palace.
speech.text: You are for dreams and slumbers, brother priest; You fur your gloves with reason. Here are your reasons: You know an enemy intends you harm; You know a sword employ'd is perilous, And reason flies the object of all harm: Who marvels then, when Helenus beholds A Grecian and his sword, if he do set The very wings of reason to his heels And fly like chidden Mercury from Jove, Or like a star disorb'd? Nay, if we talk of reason, Let's shut our gates and sleep: manhood and honour Should have hare-hearts, would they but fat their thoughts With this cramm'd reason: reason and respect Make livers pale and lustihood deject.

speech.stagedir: Enter PRIAM, HECTOR, TROILUS, PARIS, and HELENUS
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Troy. A room in Priam's palace.
speech.text: Brother, she is not worth what she doth cost The holding.

speech.stagedir: Enter PRIAM, HECTOR, TROILUS, PARIS, and HELENUS
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Troy. A room in Priam's palace.
speech.text: What is aught, but as 'tis valued?

speech.stagedir: Enter PRIAM, HECTOR, TROILUS, PARIS, and HELENUS
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Troy. A room in Priam's palace.
speech.text: But value dwells not in particular will; It holds his estimate and dignity As well wherein 'tis precious of itself As in the prizer: 'tis mad idolatry To make the service greater than the god And the will dotes that is attributive To what infectiously itself affects, Without some image of the affected merit.

speech.stagedir: Enter PRIAM, HECTOR, TROILUS, PARIS, and HELENUS
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Troy. A room in Priam's palace.
speech.text: I take to-day a wife, and my election Is led on in the conduct of my will; My will enkindled by mine eyes and ears, Two traded pilots 'twixt the dangerous shores Of will and judgment: how may I avoid, Although my will distaste what it elected, The wife I chose? there can be no evasion To blench from this and to stand firm by honour: We turn not back the silks upon the merchant, When we have soil'd them, nor the remainder viands We do not throw in unrespective sieve, Because we now are full. It was thought meet Paris should do some vengeance on the Greeks: Your breath of full consent bellied his sails; The seas and winds, old wranglers, took a truce And did him service: he touch'd the ports desired, And for an old aunt whom the Greeks held captive, He brought a Grecian queen, whose youth and freshness Wrinkles Apollo's, and makes stale the morning. Why keep we her? the Grecians keep our aunt: Is she worth keeping? why, she is a pearl, Whose price hath launch'd above a thousand ships, And turn'd crown'd kings to merchants. If you'll avouch 'twas wisdom Paris went-- As you must needs, for you all cried 'Go, go,'-- If you'll confess he brought home noble prize-- As you must needs, for you all clapp'd your hands And cried 'Inestimable!'--why do you now The issue of your proper wisdoms rate, And do a deed that fortune never did, Beggar the estimation which you prized Richer than sea and land? O, theft most base, That we have stol'n what we do fear to keep! But, thieves, unworthy of a thing so stol'n, That in their country did them that disgrace, We fear to warrant in our native place!

speech.stagedir: Enter PRIAM, HECTOR, TROILUS, PARIS, and HELENUS
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Troy. A room in Priam's palace.
speech.text: Cry, Trojans, cry!

speech.stagedir: Enter PRIAM, HECTOR, TROILUS, PARIS, and HELENUS
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Troy. A room in Priam's palace.
speech.text: What noise? what shriek is this?

speech.stagedir: Enter PRIAM, HECTOR, TROILUS, PARIS, and HELENUS
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Troy. A room in Priam's palace.
speech.text: 'Tis our mad sister, I do know her voice.

speech.stagedir: Enter PRIAM, HECTOR, TROILUS, PARIS, and HELENUS
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Troy. A room in Priam's palace.
speech.text: Cry, Trojans!

speech.stagedir: Enter PRIAM, HECTOR, TROILUS, PARIS, and HELENUS
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Troy. A room in Priam's palace.
speech.text: It is Cassandra.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Troy. A room in Priam's palace.
speech.text: Cry, Trojans, cry! lend me ten thousand eyes, And I will fill them with prophetic tears.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Troy. A room in Priam's palace.
speech.text: Peace, sister, peace!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Troy. A room in Priam's palace.
speech.text: Virgins and boys, mid-age and wrinkled eld, Soft infancy, that nothing canst but cry, Add to my clamours! let us pay betimes A moiety of that mass of moan to come. Cry, Trojans, cry! practise your eyes with tears! Troy must not be, nor goodly Ilion stand; Our firebrand brother, Paris, burns us all. Cry, Trojans, cry! a Helen and a woe: Cry, cry! Troy burns, or else let Helen go.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Troy. A room in Priam's palace.
speech.text: Now, youthful Troilus, do not these high strains Of divination in our sister work Some touches of remorse? or is your blood So madly hot that no discourse of reason, Nor fear of bad success in a bad cause, Can qualify the same?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Troy. A room in Priam's palace.
speech.text: Why, brother Hector, We may not think the justness of each act Such and no other than event doth form it, Nor once deject the courage of our minds, Because Cassandra's mad: her brain-sick raptures Cannot distaste the goodness of a quarrel Which hath our several honours all engaged To make it gracious. For my private part, I am no more touch'd than all Priam's sons: And Jove forbid there should be done amongst us Such things as might offend the weakest spleen To fight for and maintain!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Troy. A room in Priam's palace.
speech.text: Else might the world convince of levity As well my undertakings as your counsels: But I attest the gods, your full consent Gave wings to my propension and cut off All fears attending on so dire a project. For what, alas, can these my single arms? What Propugnation is in one man's valour, To stand the push and enmity of those This quarrel would excite? Yet, I protest, Were I alone to pass the difficulties And had as ample power as I have will, Paris should ne'er retract what he hath done, Nor faint in the pursuit.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Troy. A room in Priam's palace.
speech.text: Paris, you speak Like one besotted on your sweet delights: You have the honey still, but these the gall; So to be valiant is no praise at all.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Troy. A room in Priam's palace.
speech.text: Sir, I propose not merely to myself The pleasures such a beauty brings with it; But I would have the soil of her fair rape Wiped off, in honourable keeping her. What treason were it to the ransack'd queen, Disgrace to your great worths and shame to me, Now to deliver her possession up On terms of base compulsion! Can it be That so degenerate a strain as this Should once set footing in your generous bosoms? There's not the meanest spirit on our party Without a heart to dare or sword to draw When Helen is defended, nor none so noble Whose life were ill bestow'd or death unfamed Where Helen is the subject; then, I say, Well may we fight for her whom, we know well, The world's large spaces cannot parallel.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Troy. A room in Priam's palace.
speech.text: Paris and Troilus, you have both said well, And on the cause and question now in hand Have glozed, but superficially: not much Unlike young men, whom Aristotle thought Unfit to hear moral philosophy: The reasons you allege do more conduce To the hot passion of distemper'd blood Than to make up a free determination 'Twixt right and wrong, for pleasure and revenge Have ears more deaf than adders to the voice Of any true decision. Nature craves All dues be render'd to their owners: now, What nearer debt in all humanity Than wife is to the husband? If this law Of nature be corrupted through affection, And that great minds, of partial indulgence To their benumbed wills, resist the same, There is a law in each well-order'd nation To curb those raging appetites that are Most disobedient and refractory. If Helen then be wife to Sparta's king, As it is known she is, these moral laws Of nature and of nations speak aloud To have her back return'd: thus to persist In doing wrong extenuates not wrong, But makes it much more heavy. Hector's opinion Is this in way of truth; yet ne'ertheless, My spritely brethren, I propend to you In resolution to keep Helen still, For 'tis a cause that hath no mean dependance Upon our joint and several dignities.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Troy. A room in Priam's palace.
speech.text: Why, there you touch'd the life of our design: Were it not glory that we more affected Than the performance of our heaving spleens, I would not wish a drop of Trojan blood Spent more in her defence. But, worthy Hector, She is a theme of honour and renown, A spur to valiant and magnanimous deeds, Whose present courage may beat down our foes, And fame in time to come canonize us; For, I presume, brave Hector would not lose So rich advantage of a promised glory As smiles upon the forehead of this action For the wide world's revenue.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. Troy. A room in Priam's palace.
speech.text: I am yours, You valiant offspring of great Priamus. I have a roisting challenge sent amongst The dun and factious nobles of the Greeks Will strike amazement to their drowsy spirits: I was advertised their great general slept, Whilst emulation in the army crept: This, I presume, will wake him.

scene.title: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: How now, Thersites! what lost in the labyrinth of thy fury! Shall the elephant Ajax carry it thus? He beats me, and I rail at him: O, worthy satisfaction! would it were otherwise; that I could beat him, whilst he railed at me. 'Sfoot, I'll learn to conjure and raise devils, but I'll see some issue of my spiteful execrations. Then there's Achilles, a rare enginer! If Troy be not taken till these two undermine it, the walls will stand till they fall of themselves. O thou great thunder-darter of Olympus, forget that thou art Jove, the king of gods and, Mercury, lose all the serpentine craft of thy caduceus, if ye take not that little, little less than little wit from them that they have! which short-armed ignorance itself knows is so abundant scarce, it will not in circumvention deliver a fly from a spider, without drawing their massy irons and cutting the web. After this, the vengeance on the whole camp! or rather, the bone-ache! for that, methinks, is the curse dependent on those that war for a placket. I have said my prayers and devil Envy say Amen. What ho! my Lord Achilles!

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Who's there? Thersites! Good Thersites, come in and rail.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: If I could have remembered a gilt counterfeit, thou wouldst not have slipped out of my contemplation: but it is no matter; thyself upon thyself! The common curse of mankind, folly and ignorance, be thine in great revenue! heaven bless thee from a tutor, and discipline come not near thee! Let thy blood be thy direction till thy death! then if she that lays thee out says thou art a fair corse, I'll be sworn and sworn upon't she never shrouded any but lazars. Amen. Where's Achilles?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: What, art thou devout? wast thou in prayer?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Ay: the heavens hear me!

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Who's there?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Thersites, my lord.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Where, where? Art thou come? why, my cheese, my digestion, why hast thou not served thyself in to my table so many meals? Come, what's Agamemnon?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Thy commander, Achilles. Then tell me, Patroclus, what's Achilles?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Thy lord, Thersites: then tell me, I pray thee, what's thyself?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Thy knower, Patroclus: then tell me, Patroclus, what art thou?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Thou mayst tell that knowest.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: O, tell, tell.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: I'll decline the whole question. Agamemnon commands Achilles; Achilles is my lord; I am Patroclus' knower, and Patroclus is a fool.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: You rascal!

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Peace, fool! I have not done.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: He is a privileged man. Proceed, Thersites.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Agamemnon is a fool; Achilles is a fool; Thersites is a fool, and, as aforesaid, Patroclus is a fool.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Derive this; come.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Why am I a fool?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Make that demand of the prover. It suffices me thou art. Look you, who comes here?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Patroclus, I'll speak with nobody. Come in with me, Thersites.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Here is such patchery, such juggling and such knavery! all the argument is a cuckold and a whore; a good quarrel to draw emulous factions and bleed to death upon. Now, the dry serpigo on the subject! and war and lechery confound all!

speech.stagedir: Enter AGAMEMNON, ULYSSES, NESTOR, DIOMEDES, and AJAX
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Where is Achilles?

speech.stagedir: Enter AGAMEMNON, ULYSSES, NESTOR, DIOMEDES, and AJAX
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Within his tent; but ill disposed, my lord.

speech.stagedir: Enter AGAMEMNON, ULYSSES, NESTOR, DIOMEDES, and AJAX
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Let it be known to him that we are here. He shent our messengers; and we lay by Our appertainments, visiting of him: Let him be told so; lest perchance he think We dare not move the question of our place, Or know not what we are.

speech.stagedir: Enter AGAMEMNON, ULYSSES, NESTOR, DIOMEDES, and AJAX
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: I shall say so to him.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: We saw him at the opening of his tent: He is not sick.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Yes, lion-sick, sick of proud heart: you may call it melancholy, if you will favour the man; but, by my head, 'tis pride: but why, why? let him show us the cause. A word, my lord.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: What moves Ajax thus to bay at him?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Achilles hath inveigled his fool from him.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Who, Thersites?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: He.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Then will Ajax lack matter, if he have lost his argument.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: No, you see, he is his argument that has his argument, Achilles.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: All the better; their fraction is more our wish than their faction: but it was a strong composure a fool could disunite.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: The amity that wisdom knits not, folly may easily untie. Here comes Patroclus.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: No Achilles with him.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: The elephant hath joints, but none for courtesy: his legs are legs for necessity, not for flexure.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Achilles bids me say, he is much sorry, If any thing more than your sport and pleasure Did move your greatness and this noble state To call upon him; he hopes it is no other But for your health and your digestion sake, And after-dinner's breath.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Hear you, Patroclus: We are too well acquainted with these answers: But his evasion, wing'd thus swift with scorn, Cannot outfly our apprehensions. Much attribute he hath, and much the reason Why we ascribe it to him; yet all his virtues, Not virtuously on his own part beheld, Do in our eyes begin to lose their gloss, Yea, like fair fruit in an unwholesome dish, Are like to rot untasted. Go and tell him, We come to speak with him; and you shall not sin, If you do say we think him over-proud And under-honest, in self-assumption greater Than in the note of judgment; and worthier than himself Here tend the savage strangeness he puts on, Disguise the holy strength of their command, And underwrite in an observing kind His humorous predominance; yea, watch His pettish lunes, his ebbs, his flows, as if The passage and whole carriage of this action Rode on his tide. Go tell him this, and add, That if he overhold his price so much, We'll none of him; but let him, like an engine Not portable, lie under this report: 'Bring action hither, this cannot go to war: A stirring dwarf we do allowance give Before a sleeping giant.' Tell him so.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: I shall; and bring his answer presently.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: In second voice we'll not be satisfied; We come to speak with him. Ulysses, enter you.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: What is he more than another?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: No more than what he thinks he is.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Is he so much? Do you not think he thinks himself a better man than I am?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: No question.
