speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Will you subscribe his thought, and say he is?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: No, noble Ajax; you are as strong, as valiant, as wise, no less noble, much more gentle, and altogether more tractable.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Why should a man be proud? How doth pride grow? I know not what pride is.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Your mind is the clearer, Ajax, and your virtues the fairer. He that is proud eats up himself: pride is his own glass, his own trumpet, his own chronicle; and whatever praises itself but in the deed, devours the deed in the praise.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: I do hate a proud man, as I hate the engendering of toads.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Yet he loves himself: is't not strange?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Achilles will not to the field to-morrow.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: What's his excuse?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: He doth rely on none, But carries on the stream of his dispose Without observance or respect of any, In will peculiar and in self-admission.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Why will he not upon our fair request Untent his person and share the air with us?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Things small as nothing, for request's sake only, He makes important: possess'd he is with greatness, And speaks not to himself but with a pride That quarrels at self-breath: imagined worth Holds in his blood such swoln and hot discourse That 'twixt his mental and his active parts Kingdom'd Achilles in commotion rages And batters down himself: what should I say? He is so plaguy proud that the death-tokens of it Cry 'No recovery.'

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Let Ajax go to him. Dear lord, go you and greet him in his tent: 'Tis said he holds you well, and will be led At your request a little from himself.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: O Agamemnon, let it not be so! We'll consecrate the steps that Ajax makes When they go from Achilles: shall the proud lord That bastes his arrogance with his own seam And never suffers matter of the world Enter his thoughts, save such as do revolve And ruminate himself, shall he be worshipp'd Of that we hold an idol more than he? No, this thrice worthy and right valiant lord Must not so stale his palm, nobly acquired; Nor, by my will, assubjugate his merit, As amply titled as Achilles is, By going to Achilles: That were to enlard his fat already pride And add more coals to Cancer when he burns With entertaining great Hyperion. This lord go to him! Jupiter forbid, And say in thunder 'Achilles go to him.'

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: O, this is well; he rubs the vein of him.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: And how his silence drinks up this applause!

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: If I go to him, with my armed fist I'll pash him o'er the face.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: O, no, you shall not go.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: An a' be proud with me, I'll pheeze his pride: Let me go to him.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Not for the worth that hangs upon our quarrel.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: A paltry, insolent fellow!

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: How he describes himself!

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Can he not be sociable?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: The raven chides blackness.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: I'll let his humours blood.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: He will be the physician that should be the patient.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: An all men were o' my mind,--

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Wit would be out of fashion.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: A' should not bear it so, a' should eat swords first: shall pride carry it?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: An 'twould, you'ld carry half.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: A' would have ten shares.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: I will knead him; I'll make him supple.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: He's not yet through warm: force him with praises: pour in, pour in; his ambition is dry.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: My lord, you feed too much on this dislike.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Our noble general, do not do so.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: You must prepare to fight without Achilles.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Wherefore should you so? He is not emulous, as Achilles is.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Know the whole world, he is as valiant.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: A whoreson dog, that shall pelter thus with us! Would he were a Trojan!

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: What a vice were it in Ajax now,--

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: If he were proud,--

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Or covetous of praise,--

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Ay, or surly borne,--

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Or strange, or self-affected!

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Thank the heavens, lord, thou art of sweet composure; Praise him that got thee, she that gave thee suck: Famed be thy tutor, and thy parts of nature Thrice famed, beyond all erudition: But he that disciplined thy arms to fight, Let Mars divide eternity in twain, And give him half: and, for thy vigour, Bull-bearing Milo his addition yield To sinewy Ajax. I will not praise thy wisdom, Which, like a bourn, a pale, a shore, confines Thy spacious and dilated parts: here's Nestor; Instructed by the antiquary times, He must, he is, he cannot but be wise: Put pardon, father Nestor, were your days As green as Ajax' and your brain so temper'd, You should not have the eminence of him, But be as Ajax.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Shall I call you father?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Ay, my good son.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Be ruled by him, Lord Ajax.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: There is no tarrying here; the hart Achilles Keeps thicket. Please it our great general To call together all his state of war; Fresh kings are come to Troy: to-morrow We must with all our main of power stand fast: And here's a lord,--come knights from east to west, And cull their flower, Ajax shall cope the best.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Go we to council. Let Achilles sleep: Light boats sail swift, though greater hulks draw deep.

scene.title: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: Friend, you! pray you, a word: do not you follow the young Lord Paris?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: Ay, sir, when he goes before me.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: You depend upon him, I mean?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: Sir, I do depend upon the lord.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: You depend upon a noble gentleman; I must needs praise him.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: The lord be praised!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: You know me, do you not?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: Faith, sir, superficially.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: Friend, know me better; I am the Lord Pandarus.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: I hope I shall know your honour better.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: I do desire it.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: You are in the state of grace.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: Grace! not so, friend: honour and lordship are my titles. What music is this?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: I do but partly know, sir: it is music in parts.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: Know you the musicians?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: Wholly, sir.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: Who play they to?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: To the hearers, sir.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: At whose pleasure, friend

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: At mine, sir, and theirs that love music.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: Command, I mean, friend.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: Who shall I command, sir?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: Friend, we understand not one another: I am too courtly and thou art too cunning. At whose request do these men play?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: That's to 't indeed, sir: marry, sir, at the request of Paris my lord, who's there in person; with him, the mortal Venus, the heart-blood of beauty, love's invisible soul,--

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: Who, my cousin Cressida?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: No, sir, Helen: could you not find out that by her attributes?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: It should seem, fellow, that thou hast not seen the Lady Cressida. I come to speak with Paris from the Prince Troilus: I will make a complimental assault upon him, for my business seethes.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: Sodden business! there's a stewed phrase indeed!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: Fair be to you, my lord, and to all this fair company! fair desires, in all fair measure, fairly guide them! especially to you, fair queen! fair thoughts be your fair pillow!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: Dear lord, you are full of fair words.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: You speak your fair pleasure, sweet queen. Fair prince, here is good broken music.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: You have broke it, cousin: and, by my life, you shall make it whole again; you shall piece it out with a piece of your performance. Nell, he is full of harmony.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: Truly, lady, no.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: O, sir,--

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: Rude, in sooth; in good sooth, very rude.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: Well said, my lord! well, you say so in fits.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: I have business to my lord, dear queen. My lord, will you vouchsafe me a word?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: Nay, this shall not hedge us out: we'll hear you sing, certainly.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: Well, sweet queen. you are pleasant with me. But, marry, thus, my lord: my dear lord and most esteemed friend, your brother Troilus,--

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: My Lord Pandarus; honey-sweet lord,--

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: Go to, sweet queen, to go:--commends himself most affectionately to you,--

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: You shall not bob us out of our melody: if you do, our melancholy upon your head!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: Sweet queen, sweet queen! that's a sweet queen, i' faith.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: And to make a sweet lady sad is a sour offence.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: Nay, that shall not serve your turn; that shall not, in truth, la. Nay, I care not for such words; no, no. And, my lord, he desires you, that if the king call for him at supper, you will make his excuse.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: My Lord Pandarus,--

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: What says my sweet queen, my very very sweet queen?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: What exploit's in hand? where sups he to-night?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: Nay, but, my lord,--

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: What says my sweet queen? My cousin will fall out with you. You must not know where he sups.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: I'll lay my life, with my disposer Cressida.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: No, no, no such matter; you are wide: come, your disposer is sick.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: Well, I'll make excuse.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: Ay, good my lord. Why should you say Cressida? no, your poor disposer's sick.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: I spy.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: You spy! what do you spy? Come, give me an instrument. Now, sweet queen.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: Why, this is kindly done.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: My niece is horribly in love with a thing you have, sweet queen.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: She shall have it, my lord, if it be not my lord Paris.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: He! no, she'll none of him; they two are twain.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: Falling in, after falling out, may make them three.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: Come, come, I'll hear no more of this; I'll sing you a song now.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: Ay, ay, prithee now. By my troth, sweet lord, thou hast a fine forehead.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: Ay, you may, you may.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: Let thy song be love: this love will undo us all. O Cupid, Cupid, Cupid!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: Love! ay, that it shall, i' faith.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: Ay, good now, love, love, nothing but love.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: In good troth, it begins so. Love, love, nothing but love, still more! For, O, love's bow Shoots buck and doe: The shaft confounds, Not that it wounds, But tickles still the sore. These lovers cry Oh! oh! they die! Yet that which seems the wound to kill, Doth turn oh! oh! to ha! ha! he! So dying love lives still: Oh! oh! a while, but ha! ha! ha! Oh! oh! groans out for ha! ha! ha! Heigh-ho!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: In love, i' faith, to the very tip of the nose.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: He eats nothing but doves, love, and that breeds hot blood, and hot blood begets hot thoughts, and hot thoughts beget hot deeds, and hot deeds is love.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: Is this the generation of love? hot blood, hot thoughts, and hot deeds? Why, they are vipers: is love a generation of vipers? Sweet lord, who's a-field to-day?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: Hector, Deiphobus, Helenus, Antenor, and all the gallantry of Troy: I would fain have armed to-day, but my Nell would not have it so. How chance my brother Troilus went not?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: He hangs the lip at something: you know all, Lord Pandarus.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: Not I, honey-sweet queen. I long to hear how they sped to-day. You'll remember your brother's excuse?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: To a hair.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: Farewell, sweet queen.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: Commend me to your niece.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: I will, sweet queen.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: They're come from field: let us to Priam's hall, To greet the warriors. Sweet Helen, I must woo you To help unarm our Hector: his stubborn buckles, With these your white enchanting fingers touch'd, Shall more obey than to the edge of steel Or force of Greekish sinews; you shall do more Than all the island kings,--disarm great Hector.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: 'Twill make us proud to be his servant, Paris; Yea, what he shall receive of us in duty Gives us more palm in beauty than we have, Yea, overshines ourself.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. Priam's palace.
speech.text: Sweet, above thought I love thee.

scene.title: SCENE II. The same. Pandarus' orchard.

speech.stagedir: Enter PANDARUS and Troilus's Boy, meeting
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Pandarus' orchard.
speech.text: How now! where's thy master? at my cousin Cressida's?

speech.stagedir: Enter PANDARUS and Troilus's Boy, meeting
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Pandarus' orchard.
speech.text: No, sir; he stays for you to conduct him thither.

speech.stagedir: Enter PANDARUS and Troilus's Boy, meeting
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Pandarus' orchard.
speech.text: O, here he comes. How now, how now!

speech.stagedir: Enter PANDARUS and Troilus's Boy, meeting
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Pandarus' orchard.
speech.text: Sirrah, walk off.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Pandarus' orchard.
speech.text: Have you seen my cousin?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Pandarus' orchard.
speech.text: No, Pandarus: I stalk about her door, Like a strange soul upon the Stygian banks Staying for waftage. O, be thou my Charon, And give me swift transportance to those fields Where I may wallow in the lily-beds Proposed for the deserver! O gentle Pandarus, From Cupid's shoulder pluck his painted wings And fly with me to Cressid!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Pandarus' orchard.
speech.text: Walk here i' the orchard, I'll bring her straight.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Pandarus' orchard.
speech.text: I am giddy; expectation whirls me round. The imaginary relish is so sweet That it enchants my sense: what will it be, When that the watery palate tastes indeed Love's thrice repured nectar? death, I fear me, Swooning destruction, or some joy too fine, Too subtle-potent, tuned too sharp in sweetness, For the capacity of my ruder powers: I fear it much; and I do fear besides, That I shall lose distinction in my joys; As doth a battle, when they charge on heaps The enemy flying.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Pandarus' orchard.
speech.text: She's making her ready, she'll come straight: you must be witty now. She does so blush, and fetches her wind so short, as if she were frayed with a sprite: I'll fetch her. It is the prettiest villain: she fetches her breath as short as a new-ta'en sparrow.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Pandarus' orchard.
speech.text: Even such a passion doth embrace my bosom: My heart beats thicker than a feverous pulse; And all my powers do their bestowing lose, Like vassalage at unawares encountering The eye of majesty.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Pandarus' orchard.
speech.text: Come, come, what need you blush? shame's a baby. Here she is now: swear the oaths now to her that you have sworn to me. What, are you gone again? you must be watched ere you be made tame, must you? Come your ways, come your ways; an you draw backward, we'll put you i' the fills. Why do you not speak to her? Come, draw this curtain, and let's see your picture. Alas the day, how loath you are to offend daylight! an 'twere dark, you'ld close sooner. So, so; rub on, and kiss the mistress. How now! a kiss in fee-farm! build there, carpenter; the air is sweet. Nay, you shall fight your hearts out ere I part you. The falcon as the tercel, for all the ducks i' the river: go to, go to.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Pandarus' orchard.
speech.text: You have bereft me of all words, lady.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Pandarus' orchard.
speech.text: Words pay no debts, give her deeds: but she'll bereave you o' the deeds too, if she call your activity in question. What, billing again? Here's 'In witness whereof the parties interchangeably'-- Come in, come in: I'll go get a fire.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Pandarus' orchard.
speech.text: Will you walk in, my lord?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Pandarus' orchard.
speech.text: O Cressida, how often have I wished me thus!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Pandarus' orchard.
speech.text: Wished, my lord! The gods grant,--O my lord!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Pandarus' orchard.
speech.text: What should they grant? what makes this pretty abruption? What too curious dreg espies my sweet lady in the fountain of our love?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Pandarus' orchard.
speech.text: More dregs than water, if my fears have eyes.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Pandarus' orchard.
speech.text: Fears make devils of cherubims; they never see truly.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Pandarus' orchard.
speech.text: Blind fear, that seeing reason leads, finds safer footing than blind reason stumbling without fear: to fear the worst oft cures the worse.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Pandarus' orchard.
speech.text: O, let my lady apprehend no fear: in all Cupid's pageant there is presented no monster.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Pandarus' orchard.
speech.text: Nor nothing monstrous neither?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Pandarus' orchard.
speech.text: Nothing, but our undertakings; when we vow to weep seas, live in fire, eat rocks, tame tigers; thinking it harder for our mistress to devise imposition enough than for us to undergo any difficulty imposed. This is the monstruosity in love, lady, that the will is infinite and the execution confined, that the desire is boundless and the act a slave to limit.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Pandarus' orchard.
speech.text: They say all lovers swear more performance than they are able and yet reserve an ability that they never perform, vowing more than the perfection of ten and discharging less than the tenth part of one. They that have the voice of lions and the act of hares, are they not monsters?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Pandarus' orchard.
speech.text: Are there such? such are not we: praise us as we are tasted, allow us as we prove; our head shall go bare till merit crown it: no perfection in reversion shall have a praise in present: we will not name desert before his birth, and, being born, his addition shall be humble. Few words to fair faith: Troilus shall be such to Cressid as what envy can say worst shall be a mock for his truth, and what truth can speak truest not truer than Troilus.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Pandarus' orchard.
speech.text: Will you walk in, my lord?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Pandarus' orchard.
speech.text: What, blushing still? have you not done talking yet?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Pandarus' orchard.
speech.text: Well, uncle, what folly I commit, I dedicate to you.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Pandarus' orchard.
speech.text: I thank you for that: if my lord get a boy of you, you'll give him me. Be true to my lord: if he flinch, chide me for it.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Pandarus' orchard.
speech.text: You know now your hostages; your uncle's word and my firm faith.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Pandarus' orchard.
speech.text: Nay, I'll give my word for her too: our kindred, though they be long ere they are wooed, they are constant being won: they are burs, I can tell you; they'll stick where they are thrown.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Pandarus' orchard.
speech.text: Boldness comes to me now, and brings me heart. Prince Troilus, I have loved you night and day For many weary months.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Pandarus' orchard.
speech.text: Why was my Cressid then so hard to win?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Pandarus' orchard.
speech.text: Hard to seem won: but I was won, my lord, With the first glance that ever--pardon me-- If I confess much, you will play the tyrant. I love you now; but not, till now, so much But I might master it: in faith, I lie; My thoughts were like unbridled children, grown Too headstrong for their mother. See, we fools! Why have I blabb'd? who shall be true to us, When we are so unsecret to ourselves? But, though I loved you well, I woo'd you not; And yet, good faith, I wish'd myself a man, Or that we women had men's privilege Of speaking first. Sweet, bid me hold my tongue, For in this rapture I shall surely speak The thing I shall repent. See, see, your silence, Cunning in dumbness, from my weakness draws My very soul of counsel! stop my mouth.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Pandarus' orchard.
speech.text: And shall, albeit sweet music issues thence.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Pandarus' orchard.
speech.text: Pretty, i' faith.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Pandarus' orchard.
speech.text: My lord, I do beseech you, pardon me; 'Twas not my purpose, thus to beg a kiss: I am ashamed. O heavens! what have I done? For this time will I take my leave, my lord.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Pandarus' orchard.
speech.text: Your leave, sweet Cressid!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Pandarus' orchard.
speech.text: Leave! an you take leave till to-morrow morning,--

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Pandarus' orchard.
speech.text: Pray you, content you.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Pandarus' orchard.
speech.text: What offends you, lady?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Pandarus' orchard.
speech.text: Sir, mine own company.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Pandarus' orchard.
speech.text: You cannot shun Yourself.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Pandarus' orchard.
speech.text: Let me go and try: I have a kind of self resides with you; But an unkind self, that itself will leave, To be another's fool. I would be gone: Where is my wit? I know not what I speak.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Pandarus' orchard.
speech.text: Well know they what they speak that speak so wisely.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Pandarus' orchard.
speech.text: Perchance, my lord, I show more craft than love; And fell so roundly to a large confession, To angle for your thoughts: but you are wise, Or else you love not, for to be wise and love Exceeds man's might; that dwells with gods above.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Pandarus' orchard.
speech.text: O that I thought it could be in a woman-- As, if it can, I will presume in you-- To feed for aye her ramp and flames of love; To keep her constancy in plight and youth, Outliving beauty's outward, with a mind That doth renew swifter than blood decays! Or that persuasion could but thus convince me, That my integrity and truth to you Might be affronted with the match and weight Of such a winnow'd purity in love; How were I then uplifted! but, alas! I am as true as truth's simplicity And simpler than the infancy of truth.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Pandarus' orchard.
speech.text: In that I'll war with you.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Pandarus' orchard.
speech.text: O virtuous fight, When right with right wars who shall be most right! True swains in love shall in the world to come Approve their truths by Troilus: when their rhymes, Full of protest, of oath and big compare, Want similes, truth tired with iteration, As true as steel, as plantage to the moon, As sun to day, as turtle to her mate, As iron to adamant, as earth to the centre, Yet, after all comparisons of truth, As truth's authentic author to be cited, 'As true as Troilus' shall crown up the verse, And sanctify the numbers.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Pandarus' orchard.
speech.text: Prophet may you be! If I be false, or swerve a hair from truth, When time is old and hath forgot itself, When waterdrops have worn the stones of Troy, And blind oblivion swallow'd cities up, And mighty states characterless are grated To dusty nothing, yet let memory, From false to false, among false maids in love, Upbraid my falsehood! when they've said 'as false As air, as water, wind, or sandy earth, As fox to lamb, as wolf to heifer's calf, Pard to the hind, or stepdame to her son,' 'Yea,' let them say, to stick the heart of falsehood, 'As false as Cressid.'

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Pandarus' orchard.
speech.text: Go to, a bargain made: seal it, seal it; I'll be the witness. Here I hold your hand, here my cousin's. If ever you prove false one to another, since I have taken such pains to bring you together, let all pitiful goers-between be called to the world's end after my name; call them all Pandars; let all constant men be Troiluses, all false women Cressids, and all brokers-between Pandars! say, amen.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Pandarus' orchard.
speech.text: Amen.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Pandarus' orchard.
speech.text: Amen.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Pandarus' orchard.
speech.text: Amen. Whereupon I will show you a chamber with a bed; which bed, because it shall not speak of your pretty encounters, press it to death: away! And Cupid grant all tongue-tied maidens here Bed, chamber, Pandar to provide this gear!

scene.title: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.

speech.stagedir: Enter AGAMEMNON, ULYSSES, DIOMEDES, NESTOR, AJAX, MENELAUS, and CALCHAS
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Now, princes, for the service I have done you, The advantage of the time prompts me aloud To call for recompense. Appear it to your mind That, through the sight I bear in things to love, I have abandon'd Troy, left my possession, Incurr'd a traitor's name; exposed myself, From certain and possess'd conveniences, To doubtful fortunes; sequestering from me all That time, acquaintance, custom and condition Made tame and most familiar to my nature, And here, to do you service, am become As new into the world, strange, unacquainted: I do beseech you, as in way of taste, To give me now a little benefit, Out of those many register'd in promise, Which, you say, live to come in my behalf.

speech.stagedir: Enter AGAMEMNON, ULYSSES, DIOMEDES, NESTOR, AJAX, MENELAUS, and CALCHAS
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: What wouldst thou of us, Trojan? make demand.

speech.stagedir: Enter AGAMEMNON, ULYSSES, DIOMEDES, NESTOR, AJAX, MENELAUS, and CALCHAS
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: You have a Trojan prisoner, call'd Antenor, Yesterday took: Troy holds him very dear. Oft have you--often have you thanks therefore-- Desired my Cressid in right great exchange, Whom Troy hath still denied: but this Antenor, I know, is such a wrest in their affairs That their negotiations all must slack, Wanting his manage; and they will almost Give us a prince of blood, a son of Priam, In change of him: let him be sent, great princes, And he shall buy my daughter; and her presence Shall quite strike off all service I have done, In most accepted pain.

speech.stagedir: Enter AGAMEMNON, ULYSSES, DIOMEDES, NESTOR, AJAX, MENELAUS, and CALCHAS
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Let Diomedes bear him, And bring us Cressid hither: Calchas shall have What he requests of us. Good Diomed, Furnish you fairly for this interchange: Withal bring word if Hector will to-morrow Be answer'd in his challenge: Ajax is ready.

speech.stagedir: Enter AGAMEMNON, ULYSSES, DIOMEDES, NESTOR, AJAX, MENELAUS, and CALCHAS
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: This shall I undertake; and 'tis a burden Which I am proud to bear.

speech.stagedir: Enter ACHILLES and PATROCLUS, before their tent
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Achilles stands i' the entrance of his tent: Please it our general to pass strangely by him, As if he were forgot; and, princes all, Lay negligent and loose regard upon him: I will come last. 'Tis like he'll question me Why such unplausive eyes are bent on him: If so, I have derision medicinable, To use between your strangeness and his pride, Which his own will shall have desire to drink: It may be good: pride hath no other glass To show itself but pride, for supple knees Feed arrogance and are the proud man's fees.

speech.stagedir: Enter ACHILLES and PATROCLUS, before their tent
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: We'll execute your purpose, and put on A form of strangeness as we pass along: So do each lord, and either greet him not, Or else disdainfully, which shall shake him more Than if not look'd on. I will lead the way.

speech.stagedir: Enter ACHILLES and PATROCLUS, before their tent
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: What, comes the general to speak with me? You know my mind, I'll fight no more 'gainst Troy.

speech.stagedir: Enter ACHILLES and PATROCLUS, before their tent
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: What says Achilles? would he aught with us?

speech.stagedir: Enter ACHILLES and PATROCLUS, before their tent
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Would you, my lord, aught with the general?

speech.stagedir: Enter ACHILLES and PATROCLUS, before their tent
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: No.

speech.stagedir: Enter ACHILLES and PATROCLUS, before their tent
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Nothing, my lord.

speech.stagedir: Enter ACHILLES and PATROCLUS, before their tent
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: The better.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Good day, good day.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: How do you? how do you?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: What, does the cuckold scorn me?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: How now, Patroclus!

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Good morrow, Ajax.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Ha?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Good morrow.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Ay, and good next day too.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: What mean these fellows? Know they not Achilles?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: They pass by strangely: they were used to bend To send their smiles before them to Achilles; To come as humbly as they used to creep To holy altars.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: What, am I poor of late? 'Tis certain, greatness, once fall'n out with fortune, Must fall out with men too: what the declined is He shall as soon read in the eyes of others As feel in his own fall; for men, like butterflies, Show not their mealy wings but to the summer, And not a man, for being simply man, Hath any honour, but honour for those honours That are without him, as place, riches, favour, Prizes of accident as oft as merit: Which when they fall, as being slippery standers, The love that lean'd on them as slippery too, Do one pluck down another and together Die in the fall. But 'tis not so with me: Fortune and I are friends: I do enjoy At ample point all that I did possess, Save these men's looks; who do, methinks, find out Something not worth in me such rich beholding As they have often given. Here is Ulysses; I'll interrupt his reading. How now Ulysses!

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Now, great Thetis' son!

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: What are you reading?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: A strange fellow here Writes me: 'That man, how dearly ever parted, How much in having, or without or in, Cannot make boast to have that which he hath, Nor feels not what he owes, but by reflection; As when his virtues shining upon others Heat them and they retort that heat again To the first giver.'

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: This is not strange, Ulysses. The beauty that is borne here in the face The bearer knows not, but commends itself To others' eyes; nor doth the eye itself, That most pure spirit of sense, behold itself, Not going from itself; but eye to eye opposed Salutes each other with each other's form; For speculation turns not to itself, Till it hath travell'd and is mirror'd there Where it may see itself. This is not strange at all.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: I do not strain at the position,-- It is familiar,--but at the author's drift; Who, in his circumstance, expressly proves That no man is the lord of any thing, Though in and of him there be much consisting, Till he communicate his parts to others: Nor doth he of himself know them for aught Till he behold them form'd in the applause Where they're extended; who, like an arch, reverberates The voice again, or, like a gate of steel Fronting the sun, receives and renders back His figure and his heat. I was much wrapt in this; And apprehended here immediately The unknown Ajax. Heavens, what a man is there! a very horse, That has he knows not what. Nature, what things there are Most abject in regard and dear in use! What things again most dear in the esteem And poor in worth! Now shall we see to-morrow-- An act that very chance doth throw upon him-- Ajax renown'd. O heavens, what some men do, While some men leave to do! How some men creep in skittish fortune's hall, Whiles others play the idiots in her eyes! How one man eats into another's pride, While pride is fasting in his wantonness! To see these Grecian lords!--why, even already They clap the lubber Ajax on the shoulder, As if his foot were on brave Hector's breast And great Troy shrieking.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: I do believe it; for they pass'd by me As misers do by beggars, neither gave to me Good word nor look: what, are my deeds forgot?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Time hath, my lord, a wallet at his back, Wherein he puts alms for oblivion, A great-sized monster of ingratitudes: Those scraps are good deeds past; which are devour'd As fast as they are made, forgot as soon As done: perseverance, dear my lord, Keeps honour bright: to have done is to hang Quite out of fashion, like a rusty mail In monumental mockery. Take the instant way; For honour travels in a strait so narrow, Where one but goes abreast: keep then the path; For emulation hath a thousand sons That one by one pursue: if you give way, Or hedge aside from the direct forthright, Like to an enter'd tide, they all rush by And leave you hindmost; Or like a gallant horse fall'n in first rank, Lie there for pavement to the abject rear, O'er-run and trampled on: then what they do in present, Though less than yours in past, must o'ertop yours; For time is like a fashionable host That slightly shakes his parting guest by the hand, And with his arms outstretch'd, as he would fly, Grasps in the comer: welcome ever smiles, And farewell goes out sighing. O, let not virtue seek Remuneration for the thing it was; For beauty, wit, High birth, vigour of bone, desert in service, Love, friendship, charity, are subjects all To envious and calumniating time. One touch of nature makes the whole world kin, That all with one consent praise new-born gawds, Though they are made and moulded of things past, And give to dust that is a little gilt More laud than gilt o'er-dusted. The present eye praises the present object. Then marvel not, thou great and complete man, That all the Greeks begin to worship Ajax; Since things in motion sooner catch the eye Than what not stirs. The cry went once on thee, And still it might, and yet it may again, If thou wouldst not entomb thyself alive And case thy reputation in thy tent; Whose glorious deeds, but in these fields of late, Made emulous missions 'mongst the gods themselves And drave great Mars to faction.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Of this my privacy I have strong reasons.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: But 'gainst your privacy The reasons are more potent and heroical: 'Tis known, Achilles, that you are in love With one of Priam's daughters.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Ha! known!

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Is that a wonder? The providence that's in a watchful state Knows almost every grain of Plutus' gold, Finds bottom in the uncomprehensive deeps, Keeps place with thought and almost, like the gods, Does thoughts unveil in their dumb cradles. There is a mystery--with whom relation Durst never meddle--in the soul of state; Which hath an operation more divine Than breath or pen can give expressure to: All the commerce that you have had with Troy As perfectly is ours as yours, my lord; And better would it fit Achilles much To throw down Hector than Polyxena: But it must grieve young Pyrrhus now at home, When fame shall in our islands sound her trump, And all the Greekish girls shall tripping sing, 'Great Hector's sister did Achilles win, But our great Ajax bravely beat down him.' Farewell, my lord: I as your lover speak; The fool slides o'er the ice that you should break.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: To this effect, Achilles, have I moved you: A woman impudent and mannish grown Is not more loathed than an effeminate man In time of action. I stand condemn'd for this; They think my little stomach to the war And your great love to me restrains you thus: Sweet, rouse yourself; and the weak wanton Cupid Shall from your neck unloose his amorous fold, And, like a dew-drop from the lion's mane, Be shook to air.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Shall Ajax fight with Hector?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Ay, and perhaps receive much honour by him.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: I see my reputation is at stake My fame is shrewdly gored.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Go call Thersites hither, sweet Patroclus: I'll send the fool to Ajax and desire him To invite the Trojan lords after the combat To see us here unarm'd: I have a woman's longing, An appetite that I am sick withal, To see great Hector in his weeds of peace, To talk with him and to behold his visage, Even to my full of view. A labour saved!

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: A wonder!

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: What?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Ajax goes up and down the field, asking for himself.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: How so?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: He must fight singly to-morrow with Hector, and is so prophetically proud of an heroical cudgelling that he raves in saying nothing.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: How can that be?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Why, he stalks up and down like a peacock,--a stride and a stand: ruminates like an hostess that hath no arithmetic but her brain to set down her reckoning: bites his lip with a politic regard, as who should say 'There were wit in this head, an 'twould out;' and so there is, but it lies as coldly in him as fire in a flint, which will not show without knocking. The man's undone forever; for if Hector break not his neck i' the combat, he'll break 't himself in vain-glory. He knows not me: I said 'Good morrow, Ajax;' and he replies 'Thanks, Agamemnon.' What think you of this man that takes me for the general? He's grown a very land-fish, language-less, a monster. A plague of opinion! a man may wear it on both sides, like a leather jerkin.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Thou must be my ambassador to him, Thersites.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Who, I? why, he'll answer nobody; he professes not answering: speaking is for beggars; he wears his tongue in's arms. I will put on his presence: let Patroclus make demands to me, you shall see the pageant of Ajax.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: To him, Patroclus; tell him I humbly desire the valiant Ajax to invite the most valorous Hector to come unarmed to my tent, and to procure safe-conduct for his person of the magnanimous and most illustrious six-or-seven-times-honoured captain-general of the Grecian army, Agamemnon, et cetera. Do this.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Jove bless great Ajax!

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Hum!

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: I come from the worthy Achilles,--

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Ha!

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Who most humbly desires you to invite Hector to his tent,--

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Hum!

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: And to procure safe-conduct from Agamemnon.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Agamemnon!

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Ay, my lord.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Ha!

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: What say you to't?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: God b' wi' you, with all my heart.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Your answer, sir.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: If to-morrow be a fair day, by eleven o'clock it will go one way or other: howsoever, he shall pay for me ere he has me.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Your answer, sir.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Fare you well, with all my heart.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Why, but he is not in this tune, is he?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: No, but he's out o' tune thus. What music will be in him when Hector has knocked out his brains, I know not; but, I am sure, none, unless the fiddler Apollo get his sinews to make catlings on.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Come, thou shalt bear a letter to him straight.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Let me bear another to his horse; for that's the more capable creature.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: My mind is troubled, like a fountain stirr'd; And I myself see not the bottom of it.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Would the fountain of your mind were clear again, that I might water an ass at it! I had rather be a tick in a sheep than such a valiant ignorance.

scene.title: SCENE I. Troy. A street.

speech.stagedir: Enter, from one side, AENEAS, and Servant with a torch; from the other, PARIS, DEIPHOBUS, ANTENOR, DIOMEDES, and others, with torches
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. A street.
speech.text: See, ho! who is that there?

speech.stagedir: Enter, from one side, AENEAS, and Servant with a torch; from the other, PARIS, DEIPHOBUS, ANTENOR, DIOMEDES, and others, with torches
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. A street.
speech.text: It is the Lord AEneas.

speech.stagedir: Enter, from one side, AENEAS, and Servant with a torch; from the other, PARIS, DEIPHOBUS, ANTENOR, DIOMEDES, and others, with torches
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. A street.
speech.text: Is the prince there in person? Had I so good occasion to lie long As you, prince Paris, nothing but heavenly business Should rob my bed-mate of my company.

speech.stagedir: Enter, from one side, AENEAS, and Servant with a torch; from the other, PARIS, DEIPHOBUS, ANTENOR, DIOMEDES, and others, with torches
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. A street.
speech.text: That's my mind too. Good morrow, Lord AEneas.

speech.stagedir: Enter, from one side, AENEAS, and Servant with a torch; from the other, PARIS, DEIPHOBUS, ANTENOR, DIOMEDES, and others, with torches
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. A street.
speech.text: A valiant Greek, AEneas,--take his hand,-- Witness the process of your speech, wherein You told how Diomed, a whole week by days, Did haunt you in the field.

speech.stagedir: Enter, from one side, AENEAS, and Servant with a torch; from the other, PARIS, DEIPHOBUS, ANTENOR, DIOMEDES, and others, with torches
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. A street.
speech.text: Health to you, valiant sir, During all question of the gentle truce; But when I meet you arm'd, as black defiance As heart can think or courage execute.

speech.stagedir: Enter, from one side, AENEAS, and Servant with a torch; from the other, PARIS, DEIPHOBUS, ANTENOR, DIOMEDES, and others, with torches
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. A street.
speech.text: The one and other Diomed embraces. Our bloods are now in calm; and, so long, health! But when contention and occasion meet, By Jove, I'll play the hunter for thy life With all my force, pursuit and policy.

speech.stagedir: Enter, from one side, AENEAS, and Servant with a torch; from the other, PARIS, DEIPHOBUS, ANTENOR, DIOMEDES, and others, with torches
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. A street.
speech.text: And thou shalt hunt a lion, that will fly With his face backward. In humane gentleness, Welcome to Troy! now, by Anchises' life, Welcome, indeed! By Venus' hand I swear, No man alive can love in such a sort The thing he means to kill more excellently.

speech.stagedir: Enter, from one side, AENEAS, and Servant with a torch; from the other, PARIS, DEIPHOBUS, ANTENOR, DIOMEDES, and others, with torches
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. A street.
speech.text: We sympathize: Jove, let AEneas live, If to my sword his fate be not the glory, A thousand complete courses of the sun! But, in mine emulous honour, let him die, With every joint a wound, and that to-morrow!

speech.stagedir: Enter, from one side, AENEAS, and Servant with a torch; from the other, PARIS, DEIPHOBUS, ANTENOR, DIOMEDES, and others, with torches
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. A street.
speech.text: We know each other well.

speech.stagedir: Enter, from one side, AENEAS, and Servant with a torch; from the other, PARIS, DEIPHOBUS, ANTENOR, DIOMEDES, and others, with torches
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. A street.
speech.text: We do; and long to know each other worse.

speech.stagedir: Enter, from one side, AENEAS, and Servant with a torch; from the other, PARIS, DEIPHOBUS, ANTENOR, DIOMEDES, and others, with torches
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. A street.
speech.text: This is the most despiteful gentle greeting, The noblest hateful love, that e'er I heard of. What business, lord, so early?

speech.stagedir: Enter, from one side, AENEAS, and Servant with a torch; from the other, PARIS, DEIPHOBUS, ANTENOR, DIOMEDES, and others, with torches
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. A street.
speech.text: I was sent for to the king; but why, I know not.

speech.stagedir: Enter, from one side, AENEAS, and Servant with a torch; from the other, PARIS, DEIPHOBUS, ANTENOR, DIOMEDES, and others, with torches
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. A street.
speech.text: His purpose meets you: 'twas to bring this Greek To Calchas' house, and there to render him, For the enfreed Antenor, the fair Cressid: Let's have your company, or, if you please, Haste there before us: I constantly do think-- Or rather, call my thought a certain knowledge-- My brother Troilus lodges there to-night: Rouse him and give him note of our approach. With the whole quality wherefore: I fear We shall be much unwelcome.

speech.stagedir: Enter, from one side, AENEAS, and Servant with a torch; from the other, PARIS, DEIPHOBUS, ANTENOR, DIOMEDES, and others, with torches
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. A street.
speech.text: That I assure you: Troilus had rather Troy were borne to Greece Than Cressid borne from Troy.

speech.stagedir: Enter, from one side, AENEAS, and Servant with a torch; from the other, PARIS, DEIPHOBUS, ANTENOR, DIOMEDES, and others, with torches
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. A street.

speech.stagedir: Enter, from one side, AENEAS, and Servant with a torch; from the other, PARIS, DEIPHOBUS, ANTENOR, DIOMEDES, and others, with torches
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. A street.
speech.text: Good morrow, all.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. A street.
speech.text: And tell me, noble Diomed, faith, tell me true, Even in the soul of sound good-fellowship, Who, in your thoughts, merits fair Helen best, Myself or Menelaus?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. A street.
speech.text: Both alike: He merits well to have her, that doth seek her, Not making any scruple of her soilure, With such a hell of pain and world of charge, And you as well to keep her, that defend her, Not palating the taste of her dishonour, With such a costly loss of wealth and friends: He, like a puling cuckold, would drink up The lees and dregs of a flat tamed piece; You, like a lecher, out of whorish loins Are pleased to breed out your inheritors: Both merits poised, each weighs nor less nor more; But he as he, the heavier for a whore.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. A street.
speech.text: You are too bitter to your countrywoman.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. A street.
speech.text: She's bitter to her country: hear me, Paris: For every false drop in her bawdy veins A Grecian's life hath sunk; for every scruple Of her contaminated carrion weight, A Trojan hath been slain: since she could speak, She hath not given so many good words breath As for her Greeks and Trojans suffer'd death.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. Troy. A street.
speech.text: Fair Diomed, you do as chapmen do, Dispraise the thing that you desire to buy: But we in silence hold this virtue well, We'll but commend what we intend to sell. Here lies our way.

scene.title: SCENE II. The same. Court of Pandarus' house.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Court of Pandarus' house.
speech.text: Dear, trouble not yourself: the morn is cold.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Court of Pandarus' house.
speech.text: Then, sweet my lord, I'll call mine uncle down; He shall unbolt the gates.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Court of Pandarus' house.
speech.text: Trouble him not; To bed, to bed: sleep kill those pretty eyes, And give as soft attachment to thy senses As infants' empty of all thought!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Court of Pandarus' house.
speech.text: Good morrow, then.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Court of Pandarus' house.
speech.text: I prithee now, to bed.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Court of Pandarus' house.
speech.text: Are you a-weary of me?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Court of Pandarus' house.
speech.text: O Cressida! but that the busy day, Waked by the lark, hath roused the ribald crows, And dreaming night will hide our joys no longer, I would not from thee.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Court of Pandarus' house.
speech.text: Night hath been too brief.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Court of Pandarus' house.
speech.text: Beshrew the witch! with venomous wights she stays As tediously as hell, but flies the grasps of love With wings more momentary-swift than thought. You will catch cold, and curse me.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Court of Pandarus' house.
speech.text: Prithee, tarry: You men will never tarry. O foolish Cressid! I might have still held off, And then you would have tarried. Hark! there's one up.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Court of Pandarus' house.
speech.text: What, 's all the doors open here?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Court of Pandarus' house.
speech.text: It is your uncle.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Court of Pandarus' house.
speech.text: A pestilence on him! now will he be mocking: I shall have such a life!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Court of Pandarus' house.
speech.text: How now, how now! how go maidenheads? Here, you maid! where's my cousin Cressid?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Court of Pandarus' house.
speech.text: Go hang yourself, you naughty mocking uncle! You bring me to do, and then you flout me too.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Court of Pandarus' house.
speech.text: To do what? to do what? let her say what: what have I brought you to do?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Court of Pandarus' house.
speech.text: Come, come, beshrew your heart! you'll ne'er be good, Nor suffer others.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Court of Pandarus' house.
speech.text: Ha! ha! Alas, poor wretch! ah, poor capocchia! hast not slept to-night? would he not, a naughty man, let it sleep? a bugbear take him!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Court of Pandarus' house.
speech.text: Did not I tell you? Would he were knock'd i' the head! Who's that at door? good uncle, go and see. My lord, come you again into my chamber: You smile and mock me, as if I meant naughtily.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Court of Pandarus' house.
speech.text: Ha, ha!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Court of Pandarus' house.
speech.text: Come, you are deceived, I think of no such thing. How earnestly they knock! Pray you, come in: I would not for half Troy have you seen here.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Court of Pandarus' house.
speech.text: Who's there? what's the matter? will you beat down the door? How now! what's the matter?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Court of Pandarus' house.
speech.text: Good morrow, lord, good morrow.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Court of Pandarus' house.
speech.text: Who's there? my Lord AEneas! By my troth, I knew you not: what news with you so early?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Court of Pandarus' house.
speech.text: Is not Prince Troilus here?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Court of Pandarus' house.
speech.text: Here! what should he do here?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Court of Pandarus' house.
speech.text: Come, he is here, my lord; do not deny him: It doth import him much to speak with me.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Court of Pandarus' house.
speech.text: Is he here, say you? 'tis more than I know, I'll be sworn: for my own part, I came in late. What should he do here?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Court of Pandarus' house.
speech.text: Who!--nay, then: come, come, you'll do him wrong ere you're ware: you'll be so true to him, to be false to him: do not you know of him, but yet go fetch him hither; go.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Court of Pandarus' house.
speech.text: How now! what's the matter?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Court of Pandarus' house.
speech.text: My lord, I scarce have leisure to salute you, My matter is so rash: there is at hand Paris your brother, and Deiphobus, The Grecian Diomed, and our Antenor Deliver'd to us; and for him forthwith, Ere the first sacrifice, within this hour, We must give up to Diomedes' hand The Lady Cressida.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Court of Pandarus' house.
speech.text: Is it so concluded?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Court of Pandarus' house.
speech.text: By Priam and the general state of Troy: They are at hand and ready to effect it.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Court of Pandarus' house.
speech.text: How my achievements mock me! I will go meet them: and, my Lord AEneas, We met by chance; you did not find me here.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Court of Pandarus' house.
speech.text: Good, good, my lord; the secrets of nature Have not more gift in taciturnity.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Court of Pandarus' house.
speech.text: Is't possible? no sooner got but lost? The devil take Antenor! the young prince will go mad: a plague upon Antenor! I would they had broke 's neck!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Court of Pandarus' house.
speech.text: How now! what's the matter? who was here?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Court of Pandarus' house.
speech.text: Ah, ah!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Court of Pandarus' house.
speech.text: Why sigh you so profoundly? where's my lord? gone! Tell me, sweet uncle, what's the matter?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Court of Pandarus' house.
speech.text: Would I were as deep under the earth as I am above!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Court of Pandarus' house.
speech.text: O the gods! what's the matter?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Court of Pandarus' house.
speech.text: Prithee, get thee in: would thou hadst ne'er been born! I knew thou wouldst be his death. O, poor gentleman! A plague upon Antenor!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Court of Pandarus' house.
speech.text: Good uncle, I beseech you, on my knees! beseech you, what's the matter?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Court of Pandarus' house.
speech.text: Thou must be gone, wench, thou must be gone; thou art changed for Antenor: thou must to thy father, and be gone from Troilus: 'twill be his death; 'twill be his bane; he cannot bear it.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Court of Pandarus' house.
speech.text: O you immortal gods! I will not go.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Court of Pandarus' house.
speech.text: Thou must.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Court of Pandarus' house.
SCENE II. The same. Court of Pandarus' house.
speech.text: Do, do.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Court of Pandarus' house.
speech.text: Tear my bright hair and scratch my praised cheeks, Crack my clear voice with sobs and break my heart With sounding Troilus. I will not go from Troy.

scene.title: SCENE III. The same. Street before Pandarus' house.

speech.stagedir: Enter PARIS, TROILUS, AENEAS, DEIPHOBUS, ANTENOR, and DIOMEDES
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. Street before Pandarus' house.
speech.text: It is great morning, and the hour prefix'd Of her delivery to this valiant Greek Comes fast upon. Good my brother Troilus, Tell you the lady what she is to do, And haste her to the purpose.

speech.stagedir: Enter PARIS, TROILUS, AENEAS, DEIPHOBUS, ANTENOR, and DIOMEDES
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. Street before Pandarus' house.
speech.text: Walk into her house; I'll bring her to the Grecian presently: And to his hand when I deliver her, Think it an altar, and thy brother Troilus A priest there offering to it his own heart.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. The same. Street before Pandarus' house.

scene.title: SCENE IV. The same. Pandarus' house.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. Pandarus' house.
speech.text: Be moderate, be moderate.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. Pandarus' house.
speech.text: Why tell you me of moderation? The grief is fine, full, perfect, that I taste, And violenteth in a sense as strong As that which causeth it: how can I moderate it? If I could temporize with my affection, Or brew it to a weak and colder palate, The like allayment could I give my grief. My love admits no qualifying dross; No more my grief, in such a precious loss.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. Pandarus' house.
speech.text: Here, here, here he comes. Ah, sweet ducks!

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. Pandarus' house.
speech.text: O Troilus! Troilus!

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. Pandarus' house.
speech.text: What a pair of spectacles is here! Let me embrace too. 'O heart,' as the goodly saying is, '--O heart, heavy heart, Why sigh'st thou without breaking? where he answers again, 'Because thou canst not ease thy smart By friendship nor by speaking.' There was never a truer rhyme. Let us cast away nothing, for we may live to have need of such a verse: we see it, we see it. How now, lambs?

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. Pandarus' house.
speech.text: Cressid, I love thee in so strain'd a purity, That the bless'd gods, as angry with my fancy, More bright in zeal than the devotion which Cold lips blow to their deities, take thee from me.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. Pandarus' house.
speech.text: Have the gods envy?

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. Pandarus' house.
speech.text: Ay, ay, ay, ay; 'tis too plain a case.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. Pandarus' house.
speech.text: And is it true that I must go from Troy?

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. Pandarus' house.
speech.text: A hateful truth.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. Pandarus' house.
speech.text: What, and from Troilus too?

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. Pandarus' house.
speech.text: From Troy and Troilus.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. Pandarus' house.
speech.text: Is it possible?

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. Pandarus' house.
speech.text: And suddenly; where injury of chance Puts back leave-taking, justles roughly by All time of pause, rudely beguiles our lips Of all rejoindure, forcibly prevents Our lock'd embrasures, strangles our dear vows Even in the birth of our own labouring breath: We two, that with so many thousand sighs Did buy each other, must poorly sell ourselves With the rude brevity and discharge of one. Injurious time now with a robber's haste Crams his rich thievery up, he knows not how: As many farewells as be stars in heaven, With distinct breath and consign'd kisses to them, He fumbles up into a lose adieu, And scants us with a single famish'd kiss, Distasted with the salt of broken tears.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. Pandarus' house.
speech.text: My lord, is the lady ready?

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. Pandarus' house.
speech.text: Hark! you are call'd: some say the Genius so Cries 'come' to him that instantly must die. Bid them have patience; she shall come anon.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. Pandarus' house.
speech.text: Where are my tears? rain, to lay this wind, or my heart will be blown up by the root.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. Pandarus' house.
speech.text: I must then to the Grecians?

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. Pandarus' house.
speech.text: No remedy.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. Pandarus' house.
speech.text: A woful Cressid 'mongst the merry Greeks! When shall we see again?

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. Pandarus' house.
speech.text: Hear me, my love: be thou but true of heart,--

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. Pandarus' house.
speech.text: I true! how now! what wicked deem is this?

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. Pandarus' house.
speech.text: Nay, we must use expostulation kindly, For it is parting from us: I speak not 'be thou true,' as fearing thee, For I will throw my glove to Death himself, That there's no maculation in thy heart: But 'be thou true,' say I, to fashion in My sequent protestation; be thou true, And I will see thee.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. Pandarus' house.
speech.text: O, you shall be exposed, my lord, to dangers As infinite as imminent! but I'll be true.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. Pandarus' house.
speech.text: And I'll grow friend with danger. Wear this sleeve.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. Pandarus' house.
speech.text: And you this glove. When shall I see you?

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. Pandarus' house.
speech.text: I will corrupt the Grecian sentinels, To give thee nightly visitation. But yet be true.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. Pandarus' house.
speech.text: O heavens! 'be true' again!

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. Pandarus' house.
speech.text: Hear while I speak it, love: The Grecian youths are full of quality; They're loving, well composed with gifts of nature, Flowing and swelling o'er with arts and exercise: How novelty may move, and parts with person, Alas, a kind of godly jealousy-- Which, I beseech you, call a virtuous sin-- Makes me afeard.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. Pandarus' house.
speech.text: O heavens! you love me not.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. Pandarus' house.
speech.text: Die I a villain, then! In this I do not call your faith in question So mainly as my merit: I cannot sing, Nor heel the high lavolt, nor sweeten talk, Nor play at subtle games; fair virtues all, To which the Grecians are most prompt and pregnant: But I can tell that in each grace of these There lurks a still and dumb-discoursive devil That tempts most cunningly: but be not tempted.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. Pandarus' house.
speech.text: Do you think I will?

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. Pandarus' house.
speech.text: No. But something may be done that we will not: And sometimes we are devils to ourselves, When we will tempt the frailty of our powers, Presuming on their changeful potency.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. Pandarus' house.
speech.text: Nay, good my lord,--

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. Pandarus' house.
speech.text: Come, kiss; and let us part.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. Pandarus' house.
speech.text: Brother Troilus!

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. Pandarus' house.
speech.text: Good brother, come you hither; And bring AEneas and the Grecian with you.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. Pandarus' house.
speech.text: My lord, will you be true?

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. Pandarus' house.
speech.text: Who, I? alas, it is my vice, my fault: Whiles others fish with craft for great opinion, I with great truth catch mere simplicity; Whilst some with cunning gild their copper crowns, With truth and plainness I do wear mine bare. Fear not my truth: the moral of my wit Is 'plain and true;' there's all the reach of it. Welcome, Sir Diomed! here is the lady Which for Antenor we deliver you: At the port, lord, I'll give her to thy hand, And by the way possess thee what she is. Entreat her fair; and, by my soul, fair Greek, If e'er thou stand at mercy of my sword, Name Cressida and thy life shall be as safe As Priam is in Ilion.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. Pandarus' house.
speech.text: Fair Lady Cressid, So please you, save the thanks this prince expects: The lustre in your eye, heaven in your cheek, Pleads your fair usage; and to Diomed You shall be mistress, and command him wholly.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. Pandarus' house.
speech.text: Grecian, thou dost not use me courteously, To shame the zeal of my petition to thee In praising her: I tell thee, lord of Greece, She is as far high-soaring o'er thy praises As thou unworthy to be call'd her servant. I charge thee use her well, even for my charge; For, by the dreadful Pluto, if thou dost not, Though the great bulk Achilles be thy guard, I'll cut thy throat.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. Pandarus' house.
speech.text: O, be not moved, Prince Troilus: Let me be privileged by my place and message, To be a speaker free; when I am hence I'll answer to my lust: and know you, lord, I'll nothing do on charge: to her own worth She shall be prized; but that you say 'be't so,' I'll speak it in my spirit and honour, 'no.'

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. Pandarus' house.
speech.text: Come, to the port. I'll tell thee, Diomed, This brave shall oft make thee to hide thy head. Lady, give me your hand, and, as we walk, To our own selves bend we our needful talk.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. Pandarus' house.
speech.text: Hark! Hector's trumpet.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. Pandarus' house.
speech.text: How have we spent this morning! The prince must think me tardy and remiss, That sore to ride before him to the field.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. Pandarus' house.
speech.text: 'Tis Troilus' fault: come, come, to field with him.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. Pandarus' house.
speech.text: Let us make ready straight.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. The same. Pandarus' house.
speech.text: Yea, with a bridegroom's fresh alacrity, Let us address to tend on Hector's heels: The glory of our Troy doth this day lie On his fair worth and single chivalry.

scene.title: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.

speech.stagedir: Enter AJAX, armed; AGAMEMNON, ACHILLES, PATROCLUS, MENELAUS, ULYSSES, NESTOR, and others
speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: Here art thou in appointment fresh and fair, Anticipating time with starting courage. Give with thy trumpet a loud note to Troy, Thou dreadful Ajax; that the appalled air May pierce the head of the great combatant And hale him hither.

speech.stagedir: Enter AJAX, armed; AGAMEMNON, ACHILLES, PATROCLUS, MENELAUS, ULYSSES, NESTOR, and others
speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: Thou, trumpet, there's my purse. Now crack thy lungs, and split thy brazen pipe: Blow, villain, till thy sphered bias cheek Outswell the colic of puff'd Aquilon: Come, stretch thy chest and let thy eyes spout blood; Thou blow'st for Hector.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: No trumpet answers.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: 'Tis but early days.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: Is not yond Diomed, with Calchas' daughter?

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: Is this the Lady Cressid?

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: Even she.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: Most dearly welcome to the Greeks, sweet lady.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: Our general doth salute you with a kiss.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: Yet is the kindness but particular; 'Twere better she were kiss'd in general.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: And very courtly counsel: I'll begin. So much for Nestor.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: I'll take what winter from your lips, fair lady: Achilles bids you welcome.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: I had good argument for kissing once.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: O deadly gall, and theme of all our scorns! For which we lose our heads to gild his horns.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: The first was Menelaus' kiss; this, mine: Patroclus kisses you.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: O, this is trim!

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: Paris and I kiss evermore for him.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: I'll have my kiss, sir. Lady, by your leave.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: In kissing, do you render or receive?

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: Both take and give.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: I'll give you boot, I'll give you three for one.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: You're an odd man; give even or give none.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: An odd man, lady! every man is odd.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: No, Paris is not; for you know 'tis true, That you are odd, and he is even with you.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: You fillip me o' the head.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: No, I'll be sworn.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: It were no match, your nail against his horn. May I, sweet lady, beg a kiss of you?

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: You may.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: I do desire it.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
