speech.text: Why, beg, then.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: Why then for Venus' sake, give me a kiss, When Helen is a maid again, and his.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: I am your debtor, claim it when 'tis due.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: Never's my day, and then a kiss of you.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: Lady, a word: I'll bring you to your father.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: A woman of quick sense.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: Fie, fie upon her! There's language in her eye, her cheek, her lip, Nay, her foot speaks; her wanton spirits look out At every joint and motive of her body. O, these encounterers, so glib of tongue, That give accosting welcome ere it comes, And wide unclasp the tables of their thoughts To every ticklish reader! set them down For sluttish spoils of opportunity And daughters of the game.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: The Trojans' trumpet.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: Yonder comes the troop.

speech.stagedir: Enter HECTOR, armed; AENEAS, TROILUS, and other Trojans, with Attendants
speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: Hail, all you state of Greece! what shall be done To him that victory commands? or do you purpose A victor shall be known? will you the knights Shall to the edge of all extremity Pursue each other, or shall be divided By any voice or order of the field? Hector bade ask.

speech.stagedir: Enter HECTOR, armed; AENEAS, TROILUS, and other Trojans, with Attendants
speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: Which way would Hector have it?

speech.stagedir: Enter HECTOR, armed; AENEAS, TROILUS, and other Trojans, with Attendants
speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: He cares not; he'll obey conditions.

speech.stagedir: Enter HECTOR, armed; AENEAS, TROILUS, and other Trojans, with Attendants
speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: 'Tis done like Hector; but securely done, A little proudly, and great deal misprizing The knight opposed.

speech.stagedir: Enter HECTOR, armed; AENEAS, TROILUS, and other Trojans, with Attendants
speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: If not Achilles, sir, What is your name?

speech.stagedir: Enter HECTOR, armed; AENEAS, TROILUS, and other Trojans, with Attendants
speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: If not Achilles, nothing.

speech.stagedir: Enter HECTOR, armed; AENEAS, TROILUS, and other Trojans, with Attendants
speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: Therefore Achilles: but, whate'er, know this: In the extremity of great and little, Valour and pride excel themselves in Hector; The one almost as infinite as all, The other blank as nothing. Weigh him well, And that which looks like pride is courtesy. This Ajax is half made of Hector's blood: In love whereof, half Hector stays at home; Half heart, half hand, half Hector comes to seek This blended knight, half Trojan and half Greek.

speech.stagedir: Enter HECTOR, armed; AENEAS, TROILUS, and other Trojans, with Attendants
speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: A maiden battle, then? O, I perceive you.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: Here is Sir Diomed. Go, gentle knight, Stand by our Ajax: as you and Lord AEneas Consent upon the order of their fight, So be it; either to the uttermost, Or else a breath: the combatants being kin Half stints their strife before their strokes begin.

speech.stagedir: AJAX and HECTOR enter the lists
speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: They are opposed already.

speech.stagedir: AJAX and HECTOR enter the lists
speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: What Trojan is that same that looks so heavy?

speech.stagedir: AJAX and HECTOR enter the lists
speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: The youngest son of Priam, a true knight, Not yet mature, yet matchless, firm of word, Speaking in deeds and deedless in his tongue; Not soon provoked nor being provoked soon calm'd: His heart and hand both open and both free; For what he has he gives, what thinks he shows; Yet gives he not till judgment guide his bounty, Nor dignifies an impure thought with breath; Manly as Hector, but more dangerous; For Hector in his blaze of wrath subscribes To tender objects, but he in heat of action Is more vindicative than jealous love: They call him Troilus, and on him erect A second hope, as fairly built as Hector. Thus says AEneas; one that knows the youth Even to his inches, and with private soul Did in great Ilion thus translate him to me.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: They are in action.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: Now, Ajax, hold thine own!

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: Hector, thou sleep'st; Awake thee!

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: His blows are well disposed: there, Ajax!

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: You must no more.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: Princes, enough, so please you.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: I am not warm yet; let us fight again.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: As Hector pleases.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: Why, then will I no more: Thou art, great lord, my father's sister's son, A cousin-german to great Priam's seed; The obligation of our blood forbids A gory emulation 'twixt us twain: Were thy commixtion Greek and Trojan so That thou couldst say 'This hand is Grecian all, And this is Trojan; the sinews of this leg All Greek, and this all Troy; my mother's blood Runs on the dexter cheek, and this sinister Bounds in my father's;' by Jove multipotent, Thou shouldst not bear from me a Greekish member Wherein my sword had not impressure made Of our rank feud: but the just gods gainsay That any drop thou borrow'dst from thy mother, My sacred aunt, should by my mortal sword Be drain'd! Let me embrace thee, Ajax: By him that thunders, thou hast lusty arms; Hector would have them fall upon him thus: Cousin, all honour to thee!

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: I thank thee, Hector Thou art too gentle and too free a man: I came to kill thee, cousin, and bear hence A great addition earned in thy death.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: Not Neoptolemus so mirable, On whose bright crest Fame with her loud'st Oyes Cries 'This is he,' could promise to himself A thought of added honour torn from Hector.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: There is expectance here from both the sides, What further you will do.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: We'll answer it; The issue is embracement: Ajax, farewell.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: If I might in entreaties find success-- As seld I have the chance--I would desire My famous cousin to our Grecian tents.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: 'Tis Agamemnon's wish, and great Achilles Doth long to see unarm'd the valiant Hector.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: Great Agamemnon comes to meet us here.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: Worthy of arms! as welcome as to one That would be rid of such an enemy; But that's no welcome: understand more clear, What's past and what's to come is strew'd with husks And formless ruin of oblivion; But in this extant moment, faith and troth, Strain'd purely from all hollow bias-drawing, Bids thee, with most divine integrity, From heart of very heart, great Hector, welcome.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: I thank thee, most imperious Agamemnon.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: My well-famed lord of Troy, no less to you.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: Let me confirm my princely brother's greeting: You brace of warlike brothers, welcome hither.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: Who must we answer?

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: The noble Menelaus.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: O, you, my lord? by Mars his gauntlet, thanks! Mock not, that I affect the untraded oath; Your quondam wife swears still by Venus' glove: She's well, but bade me not commend her to you.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: Name her not now, sir; she's a deadly theme.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: O, pardon; I offend.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: I have, thou gallant Trojan, seen thee oft Labouring for destiny make cruel way Through ranks of Greekish youth, and I have seen thee, As hot as Perseus, spur thy Phrygian steed, Despising many forfeits and subduements, When thou hast hung thy advanced sword i' the air, Not letting it decline on the declined, That I have said to some my standers by 'Lo, Jupiter is yonder, dealing life!' And I have seen thee pause and take thy breath, When that a ring of Greeks have hemm'd thee in, Like an Olympian wrestling: this have I seen; But this thy countenance, still lock'd in steel, I never saw till now. I knew thy grandsire, And once fought with him: he was a soldier good; But, by great Mars, the captain of us all, Never saw like thee. Let an old man embrace thee; And, worthy warrior, welcome to our tents.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: 'Tis the old Nestor.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: Let me embrace thee, good old chronicle, That hast so long walk'd hand in hand with time: Most reverend Nestor, I am glad to clasp thee.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: I would my arms could match thee in contention, As they contend with thee in courtesy.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: I would they could.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: Ha! By this white beard, I'ld fight with thee to-morrow. Well, welcome, welcome! I have seen the time.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: I wonder now how yonder city stands When we have here her base and pillar by us.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: I know your favour, Lord Ulysses, well. Ah, sir, there's many a Greek and Trojan dead, Since first I saw yourself and Diomed In Ilion, on your Greekish embassy.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: Sir, I foretold you then what would ensue: My prophecy is but half his journey yet; For yonder walls, that pertly front your town, Yond towers, whose wanton tops do buss the clouds, Must kiss their own feet.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: I must not believe you: There they stand yet, and modestly I think, The fall of every Phrygian stone will cost A drop of Grecian blood: the end crowns all, And that old common arbitrator, Time, Will one day end it.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: So to him we leave it. Most gentle and most valiant Hector, welcome: After the general, I beseech you next To feast with me and see me at my tent.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: I shall forestall thee, Lord Ulysses, thou! Now, Hector, I have fed mine eyes on thee; I have with exact view perused thee, Hector, And quoted joint by joint.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: Is this Achilles?

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: I am Achilles.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: Stand fair, I pray thee: let me look on thee.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: Behold thy fill.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: Nay, I have done already.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: Thou art too brief: I will the second time, As I would buy thee, view thee limb by limb.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: Tell me, you heavens, in which part of his body Shall I destroy him? whether there, or there, or there? That I may give the local wound a name And make distinct the very breach whereout Hector's great spirit flew: answer me, heavens!

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: It would discredit the blest gods, proud man, To answer such a question: stand again: Think'st thou to catch my life so pleasantly As to prenominate in nice conjecture Where thou wilt hit me dead?

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: I tell thee, yea.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: Do not chafe thee, cousin: And you, Achilles, let these threats alone, Till accident or purpose bring you to't: You may have every day enough of Hector If you have stomach; the general state, I fear, Can scarce entreat you to be odd with him.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: I pray you, let us see you in the field: We have had pelting wars, since you refused The Grecians' cause.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: Thy hand upon that match.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: First, all you peers of Greece, go to my tent; There in the full convive we: afterwards, As Hector's leisure and your bounties shall Concur together, severally entreat him. Beat loud the tabourines, let the trumpets blow, That this great soldier may his welcome know.

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all except TROILUS and ULYSSES
speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: My Lord Ulysses, tell me, I beseech you, In what place of the field doth Calchas keep?

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all except TROILUS and ULYSSES
speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: At Menelaus' tent, most princely Troilus: There Diomed doth feast with him to-night; Who neither looks upon the heaven nor earth, But gives all gaze and bent of amorous view On the fair Cressid.

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all except TROILUS and ULYSSES
speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: Shall sweet lord, be bound to you so much, After we part from Agamemnon's tent, To bring me thither?

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all except TROILUS and ULYSSES
speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: You shall command me, sir. As gentle tell me, of what honour was This Cressida in Troy? Had she no lover there That wails her absence?

speech.stagedir: Exeunt all except TROILUS and ULYSSES
speech.sceneN: SCENE V. The Grecian camp. Lists set out.
speech.text: O, sir, to such as boasting show their scars A mock is due. Will you walk on, my lord? She was beloved, she loved; she is, and doth: But still sweet love is food for fortune's tooth.

scene.title: SCENE I. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: I'll heat his blood with Greekish wine to-night, Which with my scimitar I'll cool to-morrow. Patroclus, let us feast him to the height.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Here comes Thersites.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: How now, thou core of envy! Thou crusty batch of nature, what's the news?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Why, thou picture of what thou seemest, and idol of idiot worshippers, here's a letter for thee.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: From whence, fragment?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Why, thou full dish of fool, from Troy.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Who keeps the tent now?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: The surgeon's box, or the patient's wound.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Well said, adversity! and what need these tricks?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Prithee, be silent, boy; I profit not by thy talk: thou art thought to be Achilles' male varlet.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Male varlet, you rogue! what's that?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Why, his masculine whore. Now, the rotten diseases of the south, the guts-griping, ruptures, catarrhs, loads o' gravel i' the back, lethargies, cold palsies, raw eyes, dirt-rotten livers, wheezing lungs, bladders full of imposthume, sciaticas, limekilns i' the palm, incurable bone-ache, and the rivelled fee-simple of the tetter, take and take again such preposterous discoveries!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Why thou damnable box of envy, thou, what meanest thou to curse thus?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Do I curse thee?

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Why no, you ruinous butt, you whoreson indistinguishable cur, no.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: No! why art thou then exasperate, thou idle immaterial skein of sleave-silk, thou green sarcenet flap for a sore eye, thou tassel of a prodigal's purse, thou? Ah, how the poor world is pestered with such waterflies, diminutives of nature!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Out, gall!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Finch-egg!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: My sweet Patroclus, I am thwarted quite From my great purpose in to-morrow's battle. Here is a letter from Queen Hecuba, A token from her daughter, my fair love, Both taxing me and gaging me to keep An oath that I have sworn. I will not break it: Fall Greeks; fail fame; honour or go or stay; My major vow lies here, this I'll obey. Come, come, Thersites, help to trim my tent: This night in banqueting must all be spent. Away, Patroclus!

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: With too much blood and too little brain, these two may run mad; but, if with too much brain and too little blood they do, I'll be a curer of madmen. Here's Agamemnon, an honest fellow enough and one that loves quails; but he has not so much brain as earwax: and the goodly transformation of Jupiter there, his brother, the bull,--the primitive statue, and oblique memorial of cuckolds; a thrifty shoeing-horn in a chain, hanging at his brother's leg,--to what form but that he is, should wit larded with malice and malice forced with wit turn him to? To an ass, were nothing; he is both ass and ox: to an ox, were nothing; he is both ox and ass. To be a dog, a mule, a cat, a fitchew, a toad, a lizard, an owl, a puttock, or a herring without a roe, I would not care; but to be Menelaus, I would conspire against destiny. Ask me not, what I would be, if I were not Thersites; for I care not to be the louse of a lazar, so I were not Menelaus! Hey-day! spirits and fires!

speech.stagedir: Enter HECTOR, TROILUS, AJAX, AGAMEMNON, ULYSSES, NESTOR, MENELAUS, and DIOMEDES, with lights
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: We go wrong, we go wrong.

speech.stagedir: Enter HECTOR, TROILUS, AJAX, AGAMEMNON, ULYSSES, NESTOR, MENELAUS, and DIOMEDES, with lights
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: No, yonder 'tis; There, where we see the lights.

speech.stagedir: Enter HECTOR, TROILUS, AJAX, AGAMEMNON, ULYSSES, NESTOR, MENELAUS, and DIOMEDES, with lights
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: I trouble you.

speech.stagedir: Enter HECTOR, TROILUS, AJAX, AGAMEMNON, ULYSSES, NESTOR, MENELAUS, and DIOMEDES, with lights
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: No, not a whit.

speech.stagedir: Enter HECTOR, TROILUS, AJAX, AGAMEMNON, ULYSSES, NESTOR, MENELAUS, and DIOMEDES, with lights
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Here comes himself to guide you.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Welcome, brave Hector; welcome, princes all.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: So now, fair prince of Troy, I bid good night. Ajax commands the guard to tend on you.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Thanks and good night to the Greeks' general.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Good night, my lord.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Good night, sweet lord Menelaus.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Sweet draught: 'sweet' quoth 'a! sweet sink, sweet sewer.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Good night and welcome, both at once, to those That go or tarry.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Good night.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Old Nestor tarries; and you too, Diomed, Keep Hector company an hour or two.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: I cannot, lord; I have important business, The tide whereof is now. Good night, great Hector.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Give me your hand.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Follow his torch; he goes to Calchas' tent: I'll keep you company.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Sweet sir, you honour me.

speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: And so, good night.

speech.stagedir: Exit DIOMEDES; ULYSSES and TROILUS following
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: Come, come, enter my tent.

speech.stagedir: Exeunt ACHILLES, HECTOR, AJAX, and NESTOR
speech.sceneN: SCENE I. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.
speech.text: That same Diomed's a false-hearted rogue, a most unjust knave; I will no more trust him when he leers than I will a serpent when he hisses: he will spend his mouth, and promise, like Brabbler the hound: but when he performs, astronomers foretell it; it is prodigious, there will come some change; the sun borrows of the moon, when Diomed keeps his word. I will rather leave to see Hector, than not to dog him: they say he keeps a Trojan drab, and uses the traitor Calchas' tent: I'll after. Nothing but lechery! all incontinent varlets!

scene.title: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: What, are you up here, ho? speak.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: Who calls?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: Calchas, I think. Where's your daughter?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: She comes to you.

speech.stagedir: Enter TROILUS and ULYSSES, at a distance; after them, THERSITES
speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: Stand where the torch may not discover us.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: Cressid comes forth to him.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: How now, my charge!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: Now, my sweet guardian! Hark, a word with you.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: Yea, so familiar!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: She will sing any man at first sight.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: And any man may sing her, if he can take her cliff; she's noted.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: Will you remember?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: Remember! yes.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: Nay, but do, then; And let your mind be coupled with your words.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: What should she remember?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: List.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: Sweet honey Greek, tempt me no more to folly.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: Roguery!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: Nay, then,--

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: I'll tell you what,--

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: Foh, foh! come, tell a pin: you are forsworn.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: In faith, I cannot: what would you have me do?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: A juggling trick,--to be secretly open.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: What did you swear you would bestow on me?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: I prithee, do not hold me to mine oath; Bid me do any thing but that, sweet Greek.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: Good night.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: Hold, patience!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: How now, Trojan!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: Diomed,--

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: No, no, good night: I'll be your fool no more.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: Thy better must.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: Hark, one word in your ear.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: O plague and madness!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: You are moved, prince; let us depart, I pray you, Lest your displeasure should enlarge itself To wrathful terms: this place is dangerous; The time right deadly; I beseech you, go.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: Behold, I pray you!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: Nay, good my lord, go off: You flow to great distraction; come, my lord.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: I pray thee, stay.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: You have not patience; come.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: I pray you, stay; by hell and all hell's torments I will not speak a word!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: And so, good night.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: Nay, but you part in anger.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: Doth that grieve thee? O wither'd truth!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: Why, how now, lord!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: By Jove, I will be patient.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: Guardian!--why, Greek!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: Foh, foh! adieu; you palter.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: In faith, I do not: come hither once again.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: You shake, my lord, at something: will you go? You will break out.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: She strokes his cheek!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: Come, come.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: Nay, stay; by Jove, I will not speak a word: There is between my will and all offences A guard of patience: stay a little while.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: How the devil Luxury, with his fat rump and potato-finger, tickles these together! Fry, lechery, fry!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: But will you, then?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: In faith, I will, la; never trust me else.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: Give me some token for the surety of it.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: I'll fetch you one.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: You have sworn patience.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: Now the pledge; now, now, now!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: Here, Diomed, keep this sleeve.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: O beauty! where is thy faith?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: My lord,--

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: I will be patient; outwardly I will.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: You look upon that sleeve; behold it well. He loved me--O false wench!--Give't me again.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: Whose was't?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: It is no matter, now I have't again. I will not meet with you to-morrow night: I prithee, Diomed, visit me no more.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: Now she sharpens: well said, whetstone!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: I shall have it.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: What, this?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: Ay, that.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: O, all you gods! O pretty, pretty pledge! Thy master now lies thinking in his bed Of thee and me, and sighs, and takes my glove, And gives memorial dainty kisses to it, As I kiss thee. Nay, do not snatch it from me; He that takes that doth take my heart withal.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: I had your heart before, this follows it.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: I did swear patience.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: You shall not have it, Diomed; faith, you shall not; I'll give you something else.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: I will have this: whose was it?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: It is no matter.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: Come, tell me whose it was.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: 'Twas one's that loved me better than you will. But, now you have it, take it.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: Whose was it?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: By all Diana's waiting-women yond, And by herself, I will not tell you whose.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: To-morrow will I wear it on my helm, And grieve his spirit that dares not challenge it.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: Wert thou the devil, and worest it on thy horn, It should be challenged.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: Well, well, 'tis done, 'tis past: and yet it is not; I will not keep my word.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: Why, then, farewell; Thou never shalt mock Diomed again.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: You shall not go: one cannot speak a word, But it straight starts you.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: I do not like this fooling.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: Nor I, by Pluto: but that that likes not you pleases me best.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: What, shall I come? the hour?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: Ay, come:--O Jove!--do come:--I shall be plagued.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: Farewell till then.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: Good night: I prithee, come. Troilus, farewell! one eye yet looks on thee But with my heart the other eye doth see. Ah, poor our sex! this fault in us I find, The error of our eye directs our mind: What error leads must err; O, then conclude Minds sway'd by eyes are full of turpitude.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: A proof of strength she could not publish more, Unless she said ' My mind is now turn'd whore.'

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: All's done, my lord.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: It is.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: Why stay we, then?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: To make a recordation to my soul Of every syllable that here was spoke. But if I tell how these two did co-act, Shall I not lie in publishing a truth? Sith yet there is a credence in my heart, An esperance so obstinately strong, That doth invert the attest of eyes and ears, As if those organs had deceptious functions, Created only to calumniate. Was Cressid here?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: I cannot conjure, Trojan.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: She was not, sure.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: Most sure she was.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: Why, my negation hath no taste of madness.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: Nor mine, my lord: Cressid was here but now.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: Let it not be believed for womanhood! Think, we had mothers; do not give advantage To stubborn critics, apt, without a theme, For depravation, to square the general sex By Cressid's rule: rather think this not Cressid.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: What hath she done, prince, that can soil our mothers?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: Nothing at all, unless that this were she.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: Will he swagger himself out on's own eyes?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: This she? no, this is Diomed's Cressida: If beauty have a soul, this is not she; If souls guide vows, if vows be sanctimonies, If sanctimony be the gods' delight, If there be rule in unity itself, This is not she. O madness of discourse, That cause sets up with and against itself! Bi-fold authority! where reason can revolt Without perdition, and loss assume all reason Without revolt: this is, and is not, Cressid. Within my soul there doth conduce a fight Of this strange nature that a thing inseparate Divides more wider than the sky and earth, And yet the spacious breadth of this division Admits no orifex for a point as subtle As Ariachne's broken woof to enter. Instance, O instance! strong as Pluto's gates; Cressid is mine, tied with the bonds of heaven: Instance, O instance! strong as heaven itself; The bonds of heaven are slipp'd, dissolved, and loosed; And with another knot, five-finger-tied, The fractions of her faith, orts of her love, The fragments, scraps, the bits and greasy relics Of her o'er-eaten faith, are bound to Diomed.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: May worthy Troilus be half attach'd With that which here his passion doth express?

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: Ay, Greek; and that shall be divulged well In characters as red as Mars his heart Inflamed with Venus: never did young man fancy With so eternal and so fix'd a soul. Hark, Greek: as much as I do Cressid love, So much by weight hate I her Diomed: That sleeve is mine that he'll bear on his helm; Were it a casque composed by Vulcan's skill, My sword should bite it: not the dreadful spout Which shipmen do the hurricano call, Constringed in mass by the almighty sun, Shall dizzy with more clamour Neptune's ear In his descent than shall my prompted sword Falling on Diomed.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: He'll tickle it for his concupy.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: O Cressid! O false Cressid! false, false, false! Let all untruths stand by thy stained name, And they'll seem glorious.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: O, contain yourself Your passion draws ears hither.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: Have with you, prince. My courteous lord, adieu. Farewell, revolted fair! and, Diomed, Stand fast, and wear a castle on thy head!

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: I'll bring you to the gates.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: Accept distracted thanks.

speech.sceneN: SCENE II. The same. Before Calchas' tent.
speech.text: Would I could meet that rogue Diomed! I would croak like a raven; I would bode, I would bode. Patroclus will give me any thing for the intelligence of this whore: the parrot will not do more for an almond than he for a commodious drab. Lechery, lechery; still, wars and lechery; nothing else holds fashion: a burning devil take them!

scene.title: SCENE III. Troy. Before Priam's palace.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: When was my lord so much ungently temper'd, To stop his ears against admonishment? Unarm, unarm, and do not fight to-day.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: You train me to offend you; get you in: By all the everlasting gods, I'll go!

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: My dreams will, sure, prove ominous to the day.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: No more, I say.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: Where is my brother Hector?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: Here, sister; arm'd, and bloody in intent. Consort with me in loud and dear petition, Pursue we him on knees; for I have dream'd Of bloody turbulence, and this whole night Hath nothing been but shapes and forms of slaughter.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: O, 'tis true.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: Ho! bid my trumpet sound!

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: No notes of sally, for the heavens, sweet brother.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: Be gone, I say: the gods have heard me swear.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: The gods are deaf to hot and peevish vows: They are polluted offerings, more abhorr'd Than spotted livers in the sacrifice.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: O, be persuaded! do not count it holy To hurt by being just: it is as lawful, For we would give much, to use violent thefts, And rob in the behalf of charity.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
SCENE III. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: Hold you still, I say; Mine honour keeps the weather of my fate: Lie every man holds dear; but the brave man Holds honour far more precious-dear than life. How now, young man! mean'st thou to fight to-day?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: Cassandra, call my father to persuade.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: No, faith, young Troilus; doff thy harness, youth; I am to-day i' the vein of chivalry: Let grow thy sinews till their knots be strong, And tempt not yet the brushes of the war. Unarm thee, go, and doubt thou not, brave boy, I'll stand to-day for thee and me and Troy.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: Brother, you have a vice of mercy in you, Which better fits a lion than a man.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: What vice is that, good Troilus? chide me for it.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: When many times the captive Grecian falls, Even in the fan and wind of your fair sword, You bid them rise, and live.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: O,'tis fair play.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: Fool's play, by heaven, Hector.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: How now! how now!

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: For the love of all the gods, Let's leave the hermit pity with our mothers, And when we have our armours buckled on, The venom'd vengeance ride upon our swords, Spur them to ruthful work, rein them from ruth.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: Fie, savage, fie!

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: Hector, then 'tis wars.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: Troilus, I would not have you fight to-day.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: Who should withhold me? Not fate, obedience, nor the hand of Mars Beckoning with fiery truncheon my retire; Not Priamus and Hecuba on knees, Their eyes o'ergalled with recourse of tears; Not you, my brother, with your true sword drawn, Opposed to hinder me, should stop my way, But by my ruin.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: Lay hold upon him, Priam, hold him fast: He is thy crutch; now if thou lose thy stay, Thou on him leaning, and all Troy on thee, Fall all together.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: Come, Hector, come, go back: Thy wife hath dream'd; thy mother hath had visions; Cassandra doth foresee; and I myself Am like a prophet suddenly enrapt To tell thee that this day is ominous: Therefore, come back.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: AEneas is a-field; And I do stand engaged to many Greeks, Even in the faith of valour, to appear This morning to them.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: Ay, but thou shalt not go.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: I must not break my faith. You know me dutiful; therefore, dear sir, Let me not shame respect; but give me leave To take that course by your consent and voice, Which you do here forbid me, royal Priam.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: O Priam, yield not to him!

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: Do not, dear father.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: Andromache, I am offended with you: Upon the love you bear me, get you in.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: This foolish, dreaming, superstitious girl Makes all these bodements.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: O, farewell, dear Hector! Look, how thou diest! look, how thy eye turns pale! Look, how thy wounds do bleed at many vents! Hark, how Troy roars! how Hecuba cries out! How poor Andromache shrills her dolours forth! Behold, distraction, frenzy and amazement, Like witless antics, one another meet, And all cry, Hector! Hector's dead! O Hector!

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: Away! away!

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: Farewell: yet, soft! Hector! take my leave: Thou dost thyself and all our Troy deceive.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: You are amazed, my liege, at her exclaim: Go in and cheer the town: we'll forth and fight, Do deeds worth praise and tell you them at night.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: Farewell: the gods with safety stand about thee!

speech.stagedir: Exeunt severally PRIAM and HECTOR. Alarums
speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: They are at it, hark! Proud Diomed, believe, I come to lose my arm, or win my sleeve.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: Do you hear, my lord? do you hear?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: What now?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: Here's a letter come from yond poor girl.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: Let me read.

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: A whoreson tisick, a whoreson rascally tisick so troubles me, and the foolish fortune of this girl; and what one thing, what another, that I shall leave you one o' these days: and I have a rheum in mine eyes too, and such an ache in my bones that, unless a man were cursed, I cannot tell what to think on't. What says she there?

speech.sceneN: SCENE III. Troy. Before Priam's palace.
speech.text: Words, words, mere words, no matter from the heart: The effect doth operate another way. Go, wind, to wind, there turn and change together. My love with words and errors still she feeds; But edifies another with her deeds.

scene.title: SCENE IV. Plains between Troy and the Grecian camp.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Plains between Troy and the Grecian camp.
speech.text: Now they are clapper-clawing one another; I'll go look on. That dissembling abominable varlets Diomed, has got that same scurvy doting foolish young knave's sleeve of Troy there in his helm: I would fain see them meet; that that same young Trojan ass, that loves the whore there, might send that Greekish whore-masterly villain, with the sleeve, back to the dissembling luxurious drab, of a sleeveless errand. O' the t'other side, the policy of those crafty swearing rascals, that stale old mouse-eaten dry cheese, Nestor, and that same dog-fox, Ulysses, is not proved worthy a blackberry: they set me up, in policy, that mongrel cur, Ajax, against that dog of as bad a kind, Achilles: and now is the cur Ajax prouder than the cur Achilles, and will not arm to-day; whereupon the Grecians begin to proclaim barbarism, and policy grows into an ill opinion. Soft! here comes sleeve, and t'other.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Plains between Troy and the Grecian camp.
speech.text: Fly not; for shouldst thou take the river Styx, I would swim after.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Plains between Troy and the Grecian camp.
speech.text: Thou dost miscall retire: I do not fly, but advantageous care Withdrew me from the odds of multitude: Have at thee!

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Plains between Troy and the Grecian camp.
speech.text: Hold thy whore, Grecian!--now for thy whore, Trojan!--now the sleeve, now the sleeve!

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Plains between Troy and the Grecian camp.
speech.text: What art thou, Greek? art thou for Hector's match? Art thou of blood and honour?

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Plains between Troy and the Grecian camp.
speech.text: No, no, I am a rascal; a scurvy railing knave: a very filthy rogue.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Plains between Troy and the Grecian camp.
speech.text: I do believe thee: live.

speech.sceneN: SCENE IV. Plains between Troy and the Grecian camp.
speech.text: God-a-mercy, that thou wilt believe me; but a plague break thy neck for frightening me! What's become of the wenching rogues? I think they have swallowed one another: I would laugh at that miracle: yet, in a sort, lechery eats itself. I'll seek them.

scene.title: SCENE V. Another part of the plains.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Another part of the plains.
SCENE V. Another part of the plains.
speech.text: I go, my lord.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Another part of the plains.
speech.text: Renew, renew! The fierce Polydamas Hath beat down Menon: bastard Margarelon Hath Doreus prisoner, And stands colossus-wise, waving his beam, Upon the pashed corses of the kings Epistrophus and Cedius: Polyxenes is slain, Amphimachus and Thoas deadly hurt, Patroclus ta'en or slain, and Palamedes Sore hurt and bruised: the dreadful Sagittary Appals our numbers: haste we, Diomed, To reinforcement, or we perish all.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Another part of the plains.
speech.text: Go, bear Patroclus' body to Achilles; And bid the snail-paced Ajax arm for shame. There is a thousand Hectors in the field: Now here he fights on Galathe his horse, And there lacks work; anon he's there afoot, And there they fly or die, like scaled sculls Before the belching whale; then is he yonder, And there the strawy Greeks, ripe for his edge, Fall down before him, like the mower's swath: Here, there, and every where, he leaves and takes, Dexterity so obeying appetite That what he will he does, and does so much That proof is call'd impossibility.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Another part of the plains.
speech.text: O, courage, courage, princes! great Achilles Is arming, weeping, cursing, vowing vengeance: Patroclus' wounds have roused his drowsy blood, Together with his mangled Myrmidons, That noseless, handless, hack'd and chipp'd, come to him, Crying on Hector. Ajax hath lost a friend And foams at mouth, and he is arm'd and at it, Roaring for Troilus, who hath done to-day Mad and fantastic execution, Engaging and redeeming of himself With such a careless force and forceless care As if that luck, in very spite of cunning, Bade him win all.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Another part of the plains.
speech.text: Troilus! thou coward Troilus!

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Another part of the plains.
speech.text: Ay, there, there.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Another part of the plains.
speech.text: So, so, we draw together.

speech.sceneN: SCENE V. Another part of the plains.
speech.text: Where is this Hector? Come, come, thou boy-queller, show thy face; Know what it is to meet Achilles angry: Hector? where's Hector? I will none but Hector.

scene.title: SCENE VI. Another part of the plains.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. Another part of the plains.
speech.text: Troilus, thou coward Troilus, show thy head!

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. Another part of the plains.
speech.text: Troilus, I say! where's Troilus?

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. Another part of the plains.
speech.text: What wouldst thou?

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. Another part of the plains.
speech.text: I would correct him.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. Another part of the plains.
speech.text: Were I the general, thou shouldst have my office Ere that correction. Troilus, I say! what, Troilus!

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. Another part of the plains.
speech.text: O traitor Diomed! turn thy false face, thou traitor, And pay thy life thou owest me for my horse!

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. Another part of the plains.
speech.text: Ha, art thou there?

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. Another part of the plains.
speech.text: I'll fight with him alone: stand, Diomed.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. Another part of the plains.
speech.text: He is my prize; I will not look upon.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. Another part of the plains.
speech.text: Come, both you cogging Greeks; have at you both!

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. Another part of the plains.
speech.text: Yea, Troilus? O, well fought, my youngest brother!

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. Another part of the plains.
speech.text: Now do I see thee, ha! have at thee, Hector!

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. Another part of the plains.
speech.text: Pause, if thou wilt.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. Another part of the plains.
speech.text: I do disdain thy courtesy, proud Trojan: Be happy that my arms are out of use: My rest and negligence befriends thee now, But thou anon shalt hear of me again; Till when, go seek thy fortune.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. Another part of the plains.
speech.text: Fare thee well: I would have been much more a fresher man, Had I expected thee. How now, my brother!

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. Another part of the plains.
speech.text: Ajax hath ta'en AEneas: shall it be? No, by the flame of yonder glorious heaven, He shall not carry him: I'll be ta'en too, Or bring him off: fate, hear me what I say! I reck not though I end my life to-day.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VI. Another part of the plains.
speech.text: Stand, stand, thou Greek; thou art a goodly mark: No? wilt thou not? I like thy armour well; I'll frush it and unlock the rivets all, But I'll be master of it: wilt thou not, beast, abide? Why, then fly on, I'll hunt thee for thy hide.

scene.title: SCENE VII. Another part of the plains.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VII. Another part of the plains.
speech.text: Come here about me, you my Myrmidons; Mark what I say. Attend me where I wheel: Strike not a stroke, but keep yourselves in breath: And when I have the bloody Hector found, Empale him with your weapons round about; In fellest manner execute your aims. Follow me, sirs, and my proceedings eye: It is decreed Hector the great must die.

speech.stagedir: Enter MENELAUS and PARIS, fighting: then THERSITES
speech.sceneN: SCENE VII. Another part of the plains.
speech.text: The cuckold and the cuckold-maker are at it. Now, bull! now, dog! 'Loo, Paris, 'loo! now my double- henned sparrow! 'loo, Paris, 'loo! The bull has the game: ware horns, ho!

speech.sceneN: SCENE VII. Another part of the plains.
speech.text: Turn, slave, and fight.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VII. Another part of the plains.
speech.text: What art thou?

speech.sceneN: SCENE VII. Another part of the plains.
speech.text: A bastard son of Priam's.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VII. Another part of the plains.
speech.text: I am a bastard too; I love bastards: I am a bastard begot, bastard instructed, bastard in mind, bastard in valour, in every thing illegitimate. One bear will not bite another, and wherefore should one bastard? Take heed, the quarrel's most ominous to us: if the son of a whore fight for a whore, he tempts judgment: farewell, bastard.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VII. Another part of the plains.
speech.text: The devil take thee, coward!

scene.title: SCENE VIII. Another part of the plains.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VIII. Another part of the plains.
speech.text: Most putrefied core, so fair without, Thy goodly armour thus hath cost thy life. Now is my day's work done; I'll take good breath: Rest, sword; thou hast thy fill of blood and death.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VIII. Another part of the plains.
speech.text: Look, Hector, how the sun begins to set; How ugly night comes breathing at his heels: Even with the vail and darking of the sun, To close the day up, Hector's life is done.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VIII. Another part of the plains.
speech.text: I am unarm'd; forego this vantage, Greek.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VIII. Another part of the plains.
speech.text: Strike, fellows, strike; this is the man I seek. So, Ilion, fall thou next! now, Troy, sink down! Here lies thy heart, thy sinews, and thy bone. On, Myrmidons, and cry you all amain, 'Achilles hath the mighty Hector slain.' Hark! a retire upon our Grecian part.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VIII. Another part of the plains.
speech.text: The Trojan trumpets sound the like, my lord.

speech.sceneN: SCENE VIII. Another part of the plains.
speech.text: The dragon wing of night o'erspreads the earth, And, stickler-like, the armies separates. My half-supp'd sword, that frankly would have fed, Pleased with this dainty bait, thus goes to bed. Come, tie his body to my horse's tail; Along the field I will the Trojan trail.

scene.title: SCENE IX. Another part of the plains.

speech.stagedir: Enter AGAMEMNON, AJAX, MENELAUS, NESTOR, DIOMEDES, and others, marching. Shouts within
speech.sceneN: SCENE IX. Another part of the plains.
speech.text: Hark! hark! what shout is that?

speech.stagedir: Enter AGAMEMNON, AJAX, MENELAUS, NESTOR, DIOMEDES, and others, marching. Shouts within
speech.sceneN: SCENE IX. Another part of the plains.
speech.text: Peace, drums! Achilles! Achilles! Hector's slain! Achilles.

speech.stagedir: Enter AGAMEMNON, AJAX, MENELAUS, NESTOR, DIOMEDES, and others, marching. Shouts within
speech.sceneN: SCENE IX. Another part of the plains.
speech.text: The bruit is, Hector's slain, and by Achilles.

speech.stagedir: Enter AGAMEMNON, AJAX, MENELAUS, NESTOR, DIOMEDES, and others, marching. Shouts within
speech.sceneN: SCENE IX. Another part of the plains.
speech.text: If it be so, yet bragless let it be; Great Hector was a man as good as he.

speech.stagedir: Enter AGAMEMNON, AJAX, MENELAUS, NESTOR, DIOMEDES, and others, marching. Shouts within
speech.sceneN: SCENE IX. Another part of the plains.
speech.text: March patiently along: let one be sent To pray Achilles see us at our tent. If in his death the gods have us befriended, Great Troy is ours, and our sharp wars are ended.

scene.title: SCENE X. Another part of the plains.

speech.sceneN: SCENE X. Another part of the plains.
speech.text: Stand, ho! yet are we masters of the field: Never go home; here starve we out the night.

speech.sceneN: SCENE X. Another part of the plains.
speech.text: Hector is slain.

speech.sceneN: SCENE X. Another part of the plains.
speech.text: Hector! the gods forbid!

speech.sceneN: SCENE X. Another part of the plains.
speech.text: He's dead; and at the murderer's horse's tail, In beastly sort, dragg'd through the shameful field. Frown on, you heavens, effect your rage with speed! Sit, gods, upon your thrones, and smile at Troy! I say, at once let your brief plagues be mercy, And linger not our sure destructions on!

speech.sceneN: SCENE X. Another part of the plains.
speech.text: My lord, you do discomfort all the host!

speech.sceneN: SCENE X. Another part of the plains.
speech.text: You understand me not that tell me so: I do not speak of flight, of fear, of death, But dare all imminence that gods and men Address their dangers in. Hector is gone: Who shall tell Priam so, or Hecuba? Let him that will a screech-owl aye be call'd, Go in to Troy, and say there, Hector's dead: There is a word will Priam turn to stone; Make wells and Niobes of the maids and wives, Cold statues of the youth, and, in a word, Scare Troy out of itself. But, march away: Hector is dead; there is no more to say. Stay yet. You vile abominable tents, Thus proudly pight upon our Phrygian plains, Let Titan rise as early as he dare, I'll through and through you! and, thou great-sized coward, No space of earth shall sunder our two hates: I'll haunt thee like a wicked conscience still, That mouldeth goblins swift as frenzy's thoughts. Strike a free march to Troy! with comfort go: Hope of revenge shall hide our inward woe.

speech.stagedir: As TROILUS is going out, enter, from the other side, PANDARUS
speech.sceneN: SCENE X. Another part of the plains.
speech.text: But hear you, hear you!

speech.stagedir: As TROILUS is going out, enter, from the other side, PANDARUS
speech.sceneN: SCENE X. Another part of the plains.
speech.text: Hence, broker-lackey! ignomy and shame Pursue thy life, and live aye with thy name!

speech.sceneN: SCENE X. Another part of the plains.
speech.text: A goodly medicine for my aching bones! O world! world! world! thus is the poor agent despised! O traitors and bawds, how earnestly are you set a-work, and how ill requited! why should our endeavour be so loved and the performance so loathed? what verse for it? what instance for it? Let me see: Full merrily the humble-bee doth sing, Till he hath lost his honey and his sting; And being once subdued in armed tail, Sweet honey and sweet notes together fail. Good traders in the flesh, set this in your painted cloths. As many as be here of pander's hall, Your eyes, half out, weep out at Pandar's fall; Or if you cannot weep, yet give some groans, Though not for me, yet for your aching bones. Brethren and sisters of the hold-door trade, Some two months hence my will shall here be made: It should be now, but that my fear is this, Some galled goose of Winchester would hiss: Till then I'll sweat and seek about for eases, And at that time bequeathe you my diseases.
